note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima
div.stage: A Bell Rings. Enter Pymero, Chriſtophero, and Pedro.

sp.speaker: Pymero.
sp.l: _OPen the Ports and ſee the watch reliev'd,
And let the guards be careful of their buſines
Their vigilant eyes fixt on theſe Iſlanders,
They are falſe and deſperate people, when they find
The leaſt occaſion open to encouragement,
Cruell, and crafty ſoules, beleeve me Gentlemen,
Their late attempt, which is too freſh amongſt us,
In which againſt all armes, and honeſty,
The Governour of Ternata made ſurprize.
Of our confederate, the King of Tidore,
As for his recreation he was rowing
Betweene both Lands, bids us be wiſe and circumſpect.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It was a miſchiefe ſuddenly imagin'd;
And as ſoone done; that Governour's a feirce knave,
Unfaithfull as he is feirce too, there's no truſting;
But I wonder much how ſuch poore and baſe pleaſures,
As tugging at an oare, or skill in ſteerage,
Should become Princes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Baſe breeding love baſe pleaſure;
They take as much delight in a Baratto,
A little ſcurvy boate to row her tithly,
And have the art to turne and wind her nimbly,
Thinke it as noble too, though it be ſlaviſh,
And a dull labour that declines a Gentleman:
As we Portugalls, or the Spaniards do in riding,
In managing a great horſe which is princely:
The French in Courtſhip, or the dancing Engliſh,
In carrying a faire preſence.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He was ſtrangely taken;
But where no faith is, there's no truſt; he has paid for't
His ſiſter yet the faire and great Quiſara,
Has ſhewd a noble mind, and much love in't
To her afflicted brother, and the nobler ſtill it appeares,
And ſeaſons of more tendernes, becauſe his ruine ſtiles her abſolute
And his impriſonment adds to her profit.
Feeling all this, which makes all men admire her.
The warme beames of this fortune that fall on her,
Yet has ſhe made diverſe and noble treaties,
And propoſitions for her brothers freedome,
If wealth or honour—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Peace, peace, you are fool'd ſir;
Things of theſe natures have ſtrange outſides Pedro,
And cunning ſhadowes, ſet 'em far from us,
Draw 'em but neare, they are groſſe, and they abuſe us;
They that obſerve her cloſe, ſhall find her nature,
Which I doubt mainly will not prove ſo excellent;
She is a Princeſſe, and ſhe muſt be faire,
That's the prerogative of being royall:
Let her want eyes and noſe, ſhe muſt be beautious,
And ſhe muſt know it too, and the uſe of it,
And people muſt beleeve it, they are dam'd elſe:
Why, all the neighbour Princes, are mad for her,

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Is ſhe not faire then?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But her hopes are fairer,
And there's a haughty Maſter, the King of Bakan,
That lofty ſir, that ſpeakes far more, and louder
In his own commendations then a Cannon:
He is ſtrucken dumbe with her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Beſhrew me ſhe is a ſweet one.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And there's that hopefull man of Syana,
That ſpritely fellow, he that's wiſe and temperate,
He is a lover too.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Wou'd I were worth her looking
For; by my life I hold her a compleate one,
The very Sun I thinke, affects her ſweetneſſe,
And dares not as he does to all elſe, dye it
Into his tauny Livery.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: She dares not ſee him,
But keepes her ſelfe at diſtance from his kiſſes,
And weares her complexion in a caſe; let him but like it
A week or two, or three, ſhe would looke like a Lion;
But the maine ſport on't is, or rather wonder
The Governour of Ternata her mortall enemie,
He that has catcht her brother King is ſtrooke too,
And is arriv'd under ſafe conduct alſo,
And hoſtages of worth delivered for him;
And he brought a letter from his priſoner,
Whether compel'd, or willingly delivered
From the poore King, or what elſe dare be in't.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: So it be honourable, any thing, 'tis all one,
For I dare thinke ſhe'l do the beſt.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: 'Tis certaine
He has admittance, and ſollicites hourely.
Now if he have the tricke—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: What trick?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: The true one,
To take her too, if he be but skil'd in bat-fowling,
And lime his buſh right.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I'le be hang'd when that hits,
For 'tis not a compel'd, or forc'd affection,
That muſt take her, I gueſſe her ſtout and vertuous,
But where's your unckle ſir, our valiant Captaine,
The brave Ruy Dias all this while?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I marry,
He is amongſt 'em too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A Lover.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay,
I know not that, but ſure he ſtands in favour,
Or wou'd ſtand ſtifly, he is no Portugall elſe.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: The voyce ſays in good favour, in the liſt too
Of the privy woers, how cunningly of late
I have obſerv'd him, and how privately
He has ſtolne at all houres from us, and how readily
He has feign'd a buſineſſe to bid the Fort farewell
For five or ſixe daies, or a month together,
Sure there is ſomething—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, yes, there is a thing in't,
A thing would make the beſt on's all dance after it;
A dainty thing; Lord how this unckle of mine
Has read to me, and rated me for wenching,
And told me in what deſperate caſe 'twould leave me,
And how 'twould ſtew my bones.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You car'd not for it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I faith, not much, I ventur'd on ſtill eaſily,
And tooke my chance, danger is a Souldiers honour;
But that this man, this herbe of Grace, Ruy Dias,
This father of our faculties ſhould ſlip thus,
For ſure he is a ferriting, that he
That would drinke nothing to depreſſe the ſpirit,
But milke and water, eate nothing but thin ayre
To make his bloud obedient, that his youth
In ſpight of all his temperance, ſhould tickle,
And have a love mange on him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis in him ſir
But honourable courtſhip, and becomes his ranke too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: In me 'twere abominable Lecherie, or would be,
For when our thoughts are on't, and miſſe their levell,
We muſt hit ſomething.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Well, 'is a noble Gentleman,
And if he be a ſuitor, may he ſpeed in't.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Let him alone, our family ne're fail'd yet.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Our mad Lieutenant ſtill merry Pyniero,
Thus wou'd he do if the Surgeon were ſearching of him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Eſpecially if a warme wench had ſhot him.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: But harke Chriſtophero; come hether Pedro;
When ſaw you our brave countryman Armuſia?
He that's arriv'd here lately, and his gallants?
A goodly fellow, and a brave companion
Me thinkes he is, and no doubt truly valiant,
For he that dares come hether, dares fight any where.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I ſaw him not of late, a ſober Gentleman
I am ſure he is, and no doubt bravely ſprung,
And promiſes much nobleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I love him,
And by my troath wou'd faine be inward with him;
Pray lets go ſeeke him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Wee'l attend you ſir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: By that time we ſhalheare the burſt of buſineſſe. Ex.

div.stage: Enter Ruy Dias, Quiſara, Quiſana, and Panura.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Aunt I much thanke you for your curteſie,
And the faire liberty you ſtill allow me,
Both of your houſe and ſervice, though I be
A Princeſſe, and by that Prerogative ſtand free
From the poore malice of opinion,
And no waies bound to render up my actions,
Becauſe no power above me can examine me;
Yet my deare brother being ſtill a priſoner,
And many wandring eyes upon my waies,
Being left alone a Sea-marke, it behoves me
To uſe a little caution, and be circumſpect.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: You'r wiſe and noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Often Aunt
I reſort hether, and privately to ſee you,
It may be to converſe with ſome I favour;
I wou'd not have it knowne as oft, nor conſtru'd,
It ſtands not with my care.

sp.speaker: Quiſ●n.
sp.l: You ſpeake moſt fairely,
For even our pure devotions are examin'd.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: So mad are mens minds now.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Or rather monſtrous;
They are thick dreams, bread in foggs that know no fairneſſe.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: Madam the houſe is yours, I am yours, pray uſe me,
And at your ſervice all I have lyes proſtrate;
My care ſhall ever be to yeild ye honour,
And when your fame fals here, 'tis my fault Lady;
A poore and ſimple banquet I have provided,
Which if you pleaſe to honour with your preſence —

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I thanke ye Aunt, I ſhall be with you inſtantly,
A few words with this Gntleman.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: I'le leave ye, Exeunt. Quiſ, & Pan.
And when you pleaſe retire, I'le wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Why, how now Captaine, what affraid to ſpeak to me?
A man of armes, and danted with a Lady?
Commanders have the power to parle with Princes.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Madam, the favours you have ſtill ſhowr'd on me,
Which are ſo high above my meanes of merit,
So infinite, that nought can value 'em
But their owne goodneſſe, no eyes looke up to 'em
But thoſe that are of equall light; and luſtre,
Strike me thus mute, you are my royall Miſtris,
And all my ſervices that aime at honour,
Take life from you, the Saint of my devotions;
Pardon my wiſh, it is a faire ambition,
And well becomes the man that honours you;
I wou'd I were of worth, of ſomething neare you,
Of ſuch a royall peece, a King I wou'd be,
A mighty King that might command affection,
And bring a youth upon me might be witch ye,
And you a ſweet ſould Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Now you talke ſir;
You Portugals, though you be rugged Souldiers,
Yet when you liſt to flatter, you are plaine courtiers;
And could you wiſh me Chriſtian brave Ruy Dias?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: At all the danger of my life great Lady,
At all my hopes, at all—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Pray ye ſtay a little,
To what end runs your wiſh?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: O glorious Lady,
That I might — but I dare not ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Quiſar,
sp.l: I dare then,
That you might hope to marry me; nay bluſh not,
An honourable end needs no excuſe;
And would you love me then?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: My ſoule not dearer.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Do ſome brave thing that may entice me that way,
Some thing of ſuch a meritorious goodneſſe,
Of ſuch an unmatcht nobleneſſe, that I may know
You have a power beyond ours that preſerves you,
'Tis not the perſon, nor the royall title,
Nor wealth, nor glory that I looke upon,
That inward man I love that's lin'd with vertue,
That well deſerving ſoule workes out a favour;
I have many Princes ſuiters, many great ones,
Yet above theſe I love you, you are valiant,
An active man, able to build a fortune;
I do not ſay I dote, nor meane to marry,
Only the hope is ſomething may be done,
That may compell my faith, and aske my freedom,
And leave opinion faire.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Command deare Lady,
And let the danger be as deep as hell,
As direfull to attempt —

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Y'are too ſudden,
I muſt be rul'd by you, find out a fortune
Wiſely and hanſomely, examine time,
And court occaſion that ſhe may be ready;
A thouſand uſes for your forward ſpirit
Ye may find daily, be ſure ye take a good one,
A brave and worthy one that may advance ye,
Forced ſmiles reward poore dangers; you are a Souldier,
I wou'd not talke ſo elſe, and I love a Souldier,
And that that ſpeakes him true, and great, his vallour;
Yet for all theſe which are but womens follies,
You may do what you pleaſe, I ſhall ſtill know ye,
And though ye weare no ſword.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Excellent Lady,
When I grow ſo cold, and diſgrace my nation,
That from their hardy nurſes ſucke adventures,
'Twere fit I wore a Tombſtone; you have read to me
The ſtory of your favour, if I miſtake it,
Or grow a tenant in the ſtudy of it,
A great correction Lady—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Let's toth' banquet,
And have ſome merrier talke, and then to Court,
Where I give audience to my generall Suiters;
Pray heaven my womans wit hold; there brave Captain,
You may perchance meet ſomething that may ſtartle ye;
I'le ſay no more, come be not ſad—
I love ye. Exeunt

div.stage: Enter Pyniero, Armuſia Soza, Chriſtophero, and Emanuel.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You are welcome gentlemen, moſt worthy welcom,
And know there's nothing in our power may ſerve ye,
But you may freely challenge.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Sir we thanke ye,
And reſt your ſervants too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye are worthy Portugals,
You ſhew the bravery of your minds and ſpirits;
The nature of our country too, that brings forth
Stirring, unwearied ſoules to ſeeke adventures;
Minds never ſatisfied with ſearch of honour
Where time is, & the ſunne gives light, brave countrimen,
Our names are known, new worlds diſcloſe their riches,
Their beauties, and their prides to our embraces;
And we the firſt of nations find theſe wonders.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Theſe noble thoughts ſir, have intic'd us forward,
And minds unapt for eaſe to ſee theſe miracles,
In which we find report a poore relater;
We are arriv'd among the bleſſed I ſtands,
Where every wind that riſes blowes perfumes;
And every breath of aire is like an Incence:
The treaſure of the Sun dwels here, each tree
As if it envied the old Paradice,
Strives to bring forth immortall fruit; the ſpices
Renewing nature, though not deifying,
And when that fals by time, ſcorning the earth,
The ſullen earth ſhould taint or ſucke their beauties,
But as we dreamt, for ever ſo preſerve us:
Nothing we ſee, but breeds an admiration;
The very rivers as we floate along,
Throw up their pearles, and curle their heads to court us;
The bowels of the earth ſwell with the births
Of thouſand unknowne gems, and thouſand riches;
Nothing that beares a life, but beings a treaſure;
The people they ſhew brave too, civill manner'd,
Proportioned like the Maſtres of great minds,
The women which I wonder at—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye ſpeake well.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Of delicate aſpects, faire, clearly beauteous,
And to that admiration, ſweet and courteous.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And is not that a good thing? brave Armuſia
You never ſaw the Court before?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No certaine,
But that I ſee a wonder too, all excellent,
The Government exact.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Ye ſhall ſee anon,
That that will make ye ſtart indeed, ſuch beauties,
Such riches, and ſuch forme.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: We are fire already;
The wealthy Magazine of nature ſure
Inhabits here.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Theſe ſure are all Ilanders.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, and great Princes too, and luſty lovers.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: They are goodly perſons; what might he be ſigneor
That beares ſo proud a ſtate?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: King of Bakam,
A fellow that farts terrour,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: He lookes highly,
Sure he was begot o'th top of a ſteeple.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: It may well be,
For you ſhall heare him ring anon.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That is Syana,
And a brave temper'd fellow, and more valiant.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: What rugged face is that?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That's the great Governour,
The man ſurpriz'd our friend, I told ye of him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Has dangerous eyes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: A perilous theefe, and ſubtle.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: And to that ſubtlety a heart of Iron.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yet the young Lady makes it melt.

sp.speaker: Ar,
sp.l: They ſtart all,
And thunder in the eyes.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Away ye poore ones,
Am I in competition with ſuch bubbles?
My vertue, and my name rank'd with ſuch trifles?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Ye ſpeake loud.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Young-man, I will ſpeake louder;
Can any man but I, deſerve her favour,
You petty Princes? Princes flie at one another.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He will put 'em all in's pocket.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Thou proud mad thing be not ſo full of glory,
So full of vanity.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: How: I contemne thee,
And that fort-keeping fellow,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How the dog lookes,
The bandog Governour?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ha, why?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Away thing,
And keepe your ranke with thoſe that fit your toyalty;
Call out the Princeſſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Doſt thou know me bladder,
Thou inſolent impoſtume?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I deſpiſe thee;

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Art thou acquainted with my nature baby?
Let my revenge for injuries? darſt thou hold me
So far behind thy file, I cannot reach thee?
What canſt thou merit?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Merit? I am above it;
I am equall with all honours, all atchievements,
And what is great and worthy; the beſt doer
I keepe at my command, fortune's my ſervant,
'Tis in my power now to deſpiſe ſuch wretches,
To looke upon ye ſlightly, and neglect ye,
And but ſhe daines at ſome houres to remember ye,
And people have beſtowed ſome titles one ye,
I ſhould forget your names—

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: Mercy of me;
What a blowne foole has ſelfe affection
Made of this fellow? did not the Queene your mother,
Long for bellows, and bagpipes when ſhe was great with ye,
She brought forth ſuch a windy birth?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: 'Tis ten to one
She eate a Drum, and was deliver'd of alarum,
Or elſe he was ſwadled in an old ſaile when he was yong.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He ſwels too mainly with his meditations;
Faith talke a little hanſomer, ride ſoftly
That we may be able to hold way with ye, we are Princes,
But thoſe are but poore things to you; talke wiſer,
'Twill well become your mightineſſe; talke leſſe,
That men may thinke ye can do more.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Talke truth,
That men may thinke ye are honeſt, and beleeve ye,
Or talke your ſelfe aſleep, for I am weary of you.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Why? I can talke and do.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: That wou'd do excellent.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And tell you, only I deſerve the Princeſſe,
And make good only I, if you dare, you ſir,
Or your Syanas Prince.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Heres a ſtorme toward,
Me thinkes it ſings already, to him Governour.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Here lies my proofe. Draw.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: And mine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I'le be ſhort with ye,
For theſe long arguments I was never good at.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How white the boaſter lookes?

div.stage: Enter Ruy Dias, Quiſara, Quiſana, Panura.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I ſee he lackes faith.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: For ſhame forbeare great Princes, rule your angers,
You violate the freedome of this place,
The ſtate and royalty—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: He's well contented
It ſeemes, and ſo I have done.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Is this ſhe ſignior?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is the Princeſſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: She is ſweet and goodly,
An admirable forme, they have cauſe to juſtle.
Quiſar. Ye wrong me and my court, ye forward Princes;
Comes your love wrapt in violence to ſeeke us?
Is't fit though you be great, my pretence ſhould be
Staind, and polluted with your bloudy rages?
My privacies affrighted with your ſwords?
He that loves me, loves my command; be temper'd,
Or be no more what ye profeſſe, my Servants.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: We are calme as peace.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What command ſhe carries?
And what a ſparkling Majeſty flyes from her?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Is it ye love to do? ye ſhall find danger,
And danger that ſhall ſtart your reſolutions,
But not this way; 'tis not contention,
Who loves me to my face beſt, or who can flatter moſt
Can carry me, he that deſerves my favour,
And will enjoy what I bring, love and Majeſty,
Muſt win me with his worth; muſt travell for me;
Muſt put his haſty rage off, and put on
A well confirm'd, temperate, and true vallour.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: But ſhew the way.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: And will, and then ſhew you
A will to tread the way, I'le ſay ye are worthy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: What taske now
Will ſhe turne 'em to? theſe hot youths,
I feare will find a coolling card, I read in her eyes
Something that has ſome ſwinge muſt flye amongſt 'em;
By this hand I love her a little now.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: 'Tis not unknown to you
I had a royall brother, now miſerable,
And Priſoner to that man; if I were ambitious,
Gap'd for that glory was ne're borne with me,
There they ſhould lye as miſeries upon him:
If I were covetous, and my heart ſet
On riches, and thoſe baſe effects that follow
On pleaſures uncontroul'd, or ſafe revenges,
There he ſhould dye, his death would give me all theſe;
For then ſtood I up abſolute to do all;
Yet all theſe flattering ſhews of dignity,
Theſe golden dreames of greatneſſe cannot force
To forget nature and my faire affection.
Therefore that man that would be known my lover,
Muſt be known his redeemer, and muſt bring him
Either alive or dead to my embraces,
For even his bones I ſcorne ſhall feele ſuch ſlavery,
Or ſeeke another Miſtris, 'twill be hard
To do this, wondrous hard, a great adventure,
Fit for a ſpirit of an equall greatneſſe;
But being done, the reward is worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: How they ſtand gaping all?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Ruy Dias cold?
Not flye like fire into it? may be you doubt me,
He that ſhall do this is my husband Prince;
By the bright heavens he is, by whoſe juſtice
I openly proclame it; if I lye,
Or ſeeke to ſet you on with ſubtilty,
Let that meet with me, and reward my falſhood.
No ſtirring yet, no ſtart into a bravery?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Madam, it may be, but being a maine danger,
Your Grace muſt give me leave to looke about me,
And take a little time, the cauſe will aske it,
Great acts require great counſells.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Take your pleaſure,
I feare the Portugall.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I'le raiſe an Army
That ſhall bring backe his Iſland fort and all,
And fixe it here.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: How long will this be doing?
You ſhould have begun in your Grandfathers dayes.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: What may be,
And what my power can promiſe nobleſt Lady,
My will I am ſure ſtandsfaire.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Faire be your fortune,
Few promiſes are beſt, and faire performance.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Theſe cannot doe,
Their power and arts are weake ones.
'Tis in my will, I have this King your brother,
He is my priſoner, I accept your priſoner,
And bleſſe the faire occaſion that atchiev'd him:
I love ye, and I honor ye, but ſpeake
Whether alive or dead he ſhall be rendred,
And ſee how readily, how in an inſtant,
Quicke as your wiſhes Lady—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: No, I ſcorne ye,
You and your courteſie; I hate your love ſir;
And ere I would ſo baſely win his liberty,
I would ſtudy to forget he was my brother;
By force he was taken; he that ſhall enjoy me,
Shall fetch him backe by force, or never know me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: As I live, a rare wench.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: She has a noble ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: By force?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Yes ſir by force, and make you glad too
To let him goe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: How? you may looke nobler on me,
And thinke me no ſuch boy; by force he muſt not,
For your love much may be.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Put up your paſſion,
And pack ye home, I ſay, by force, and ſuddenly.
He lies there till he rots elſe, although I love him
Moſt tenderly and dearly, as a brother,
And out of there reſpects would joy to ſee him;
Yet to receive him as thy courtelie,
With all the honour thou couldſt adde unto him
From his hands that moſt hate him, I had rather
Though no condition were propounded for him,
See him far ſunke i'th earth, and there forget him.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Your hopes are gelt good Governour.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: A rare woman.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Lady,
I'le pull this pride, I'le quench this bravery,
And turne your glorious ſcorne to teares and howlings;
I will proud Princeſſe; this neglect of me
Shall make thy brother King moſt miſerable;
Shall turne him into curſes 'gainſt thy crueltie:
For where before I us'd him like a King,
And did thoſe Royall Offices unto him,
Now he ſhall lie a ſad lump in a dungeon,
Loden with chaines and fetters, colds and hunger,
Darkneſſe and lingring death for his companions;
And let me ſee who dare attempt his reſcue,
What deſperate foole; looke toward it; farwell,
And when thou know'ſt him thus, lament thy follies,
Nay I will make thee kneele to take my offer:
Once more farwell, and put thy truſt in puppits. Exit.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: If none dare undertake it, I'le live a mourner.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: You cannot want.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: You muſt not.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt dangerous,
And wiſe men wou'd proceed with care & counſell,
Yet ſome way would I knnw—
Walke with me Gentlemen— Exeunt. Manent Arm. & his Comp.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How doe you like her ſpirit?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: 'Tis a cleare one,
Clod with no dirty ſtuffe, ſhe is all pure honor.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The braveſt wench I ever look'd upon,
And of the ſtrongeſt parts, ſhe is moſt faire,
Yet her mind ſuch a mirrour—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: What an action
Wou'd this be to put forward one, what a glory,
And what an everlaſting wealth to end it?
Methinkes my ſoule is ſtrangely rais'd.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: To ſtep into it,
Juſt while they thinke, and ere they have determin'd
To bring the King off.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Things have been done as dangerous.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And proſper'd beſt when they were leaſt conſiderd.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Bleſſe me my hopes,
And you my friends aſſiſt me.
None but our companions.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: You deale wiſely,
And if we ſhrinke the name of ſlaves dye with us.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Stay not for ſecond thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am determin'd;
And though I loſe, it ſhall be ſung, I was valiant,
And my brave offer ſhall be turn'd to ſtory,
Worthy the Princeſſe tongue. A boat that's all
That's unprovided, and habits like to merchants,
The reſt wee'l councell as we goe.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Away then,
Fortune lookes faire on thoſe, make haſte to win her.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: I Have kept many a man, and many a great one,
Yet I confeſſe, I nere ſaw before
A man of ſuch a ſufferance; he lies now
Where I would not lay my dog, for ſure 'twou'd kill him.
Where neither light or comfort can come neare him;
Nor aire, nor earth that's wholſome; it grieves me
To ſee a mighty King with all his glory,
Sunke o'th' ſudden to the bottome of a dungeon.
Whether ſhould we deſcend that are poore Raſcals
If we had our deſerts?

sp.speaker: 1 Mo.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtrange wonder,
Load him with Irons, oppreſſe him with contempts,
Which are the Governors commands, give him nothing,
Or ſo little, to ſuſtaine life, 'tis next nothing;
They ſtir not him, he ſmiles upon his miſeries,
And beares 'em with ſuch ſtrength as if his nature
Had been nurs'd up, and foſter'd with calamities.
He gives no ill words, curſes, nor repines not,
Blames nothing, hopes in nothing we can heare of;
And in the midſt of all theſe frights, feares nothing.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: I'le be ſworne
He feares not, for even when I ſhake for him,
As many times my pitty will compell me,
When other ſoules that beare nor halfe his burthen,
Shrinke in their powers, and burſt with their oppreſſions;
Then will he ſing, wooe his afflictions,
And court 'em in ſad aires, as if he wou'd wed 'em.
That's more then we have heard yet, we are only
Appointed for his guard, but not ſo neare him,
If we could heare that wonder—

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Many times
I feare the Governour ſhould come to know it;
For his voice ſo affects me, ſo delights me,
That when I find his houre, I have Muſicke ready,
And it ſtirs me infinitely, be but ſtill and private,
And you may chance to heare.

l.hi: King appeares loden with chaine, his head, arms only above

sp.l: We will not ſtir ſir;
This is a ſuddaine change, but who darres blame it.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Now harke and melt, for I am ſure I ſhall;
Stand ſilent, what ſtubbourne weight of chaines—
Yet he lookes temperately.
His eyes not ſunke, and his complexion firme ſtill,
No wildneſſe, no diſtemper'd touch upon him.
How conſtantly he ſmiles, and how undanted?
With what a Majeſty he heaves his head up? Muſick.

sp.speaker: Ke.
sp.l: Now marke, I know he wil ſing; do not diſturb him.
Your allowance from the Governor, wou'd it were more ſir,
Or in my power to make it hanſomer.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do not transgreſſe thy charge, I take his bounty,
And fortune, whileſt I beare a mind contented,
Not leavend with the glory I am falne from,
Nor hang upon vaine hopes, that may corrupt me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Thou art my ſlave, and I appeare above thee.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: The Governor himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What, at your banquet?
And in ſuch ſtate, and with ſuch change of ſervice?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Nature's no glutton ſir, a little ſerves her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: This diet's holſome then.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I beg no better.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: A calme contented mind, give him leſſe next;
Theſe full meales will oppreſſe his health, his Grace
Is of a tender, and pure conſtitution,
And ſuch repletions—

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Mocke, mock, it moves not me ſir,
Thy mirthes, as do thy miſchiefes flie behind me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Ye carry it handſomely, but tell me patience,
Do not you curſe the brave and royall Lady
Your gratious ſiſter? do not you damn her pitty,
Damn twenty times a day, and dam it ſeriouſly?
Do not you ſweare aloud too, cry and kick?
The very ſoule ſweat in thee with the agony
Of her contempt of me? couldſt not thou eate her
For being ſo injurious to thy fortune,
Thy faire and happy fortune? couldſt not thou wiſh her
A Baſtard, or a whore, fame might proclame her
Black ugly fame, or that thou hadſt had no ſiſter?
Spitting the generall name out, and the nature;
Blaſpheming heaven for making ſuch a miſchiefe;
For giving power to pride, and will to woman?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No Tyrant, no, I bleſſe and love her for it;
And though her ſcorne of thee, had laid up for me
As many plagues as the corrupted aire breeds,
As many miſchiefes as the houres have minutes.
As many formes of death, as doubt can figure;
Yet I ſhould love her more ſtill, and more honour her;
All thou canſt lay upon me, cannot bend me,
No not the ſtroke of death, that I deſpiſe too:
For if feare could poſſeſſe me, thou hadſt won me;
As little from this houre I prize thy flatteries,
And leſſe then thoſe thy prayers, though thou wouldſt kneele to me;
And if ſhe be not Miſtris of this nature,
She is none of mine, no kin, and I contemne her.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Are you ſo valiant ſir?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Yes, and ſo fortunate;
For he that holds my conſtancy ſtill conquers;
Hadſt thou preſerv'd me as a noble enemy,
And as at firſt, made my reſtraint ſeeme to me
But only as the ſhadow of captivity,
I had ſtill ſpoke thee noble, ſtill declar'd thee
A valiant, great, and worthy man, ſtill lov'd thee,
And ſtill prefer'd thy faire love to my ſiſter;
But to compell this from me with a miſery,
A moſt inhumane, and unhanſome ſlavery —

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You will relent for all this talke I feare not,
And put your wits a worke agen.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: You are cozen'd;
Or if I were ſo weake to be wrought to it,
So fearefull to give way to ſo much poverty,
How I ſhould curſe her heart if ſhe conſented.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You ſhall write and entreat or —

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do thy utmoſt,
And e'ne in all thy tortures I'le laugh at thee,
I'le thinke thee no more valiant, but a villaine;
Nothing thou haſt done brave, but like a theefe,
Atchiev'd by craft, and kept by cruelty;
Nothing thou canſt deſerve, thou art unhoneſt;
Nor no way live to build a name, thou art barbarous.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Down with him low enough, there let him murmur,
And ſee his dyet be ſo light and little,
He grow not thus high hearted on't, I will coole ye,
And make ye cry for mercy, and be ready
To worke my ends, and willingly; and your ſiſter taken downe,
Your ſcornefull, cruell ſiſter ſhall repent too,
And ſue to me for grace.
Give him no liberty,
But let his bands be doubled, his eaſe leſſened;
Nothing his heart deſires, but vexe and torture him:
Let him not ſleepe, nothing that's deare to nature
Let him enjoy; yet take heed that he dye not;
Keepe him as neere death, and as willing to embrace it,
But ſee he arrive not at it; I will humble him,
And her ſtout heart that ſtands on ſuch defiance;
And let me ſee her champions that dare venture
Her high and mighty wooers, keepe your guards cloſe,
And as yon love your lives be diligent,
And what I charge, obſerve.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: We ſhall be dutifull. Exit. Gov.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I'le pull your courage King and all your bravery.
Moſt certaine he is reſolved nothing can ſtir him;
For if he had but any part about him
Gave way to feare or hope, he durſt not talke thus,
And do thus ſtoutly too, as willingly,
And quietly he ſunke downe to his ſorrows,
As ſome men to their ſleepes.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: Yes, and ſleepes with 'em;
So litle he regards them, ther's the wonder,
And often ſoundly ſleepes, wou'd I durſt pitty him,
Or wou'd it were in my will, but we are ſervants,
And tyed unto command.
I wiſh him better,
But much I feare has found his tombe already,
We muſt obſerve our guards.
He cannot laſt long,
And when he is dead, he is free.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: That's the moſt cruelty,
That we muſt keepe him living.
That's as he pleaſe;
For that man that reſolves, needs no Phiſitian. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Armuſia, Soza, Emanuel like merchants, Arm'd underneath.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Our proſperous paſſage was an omen to us,
A lucky and a faire omen.

sp.speaker: Omnes
sp.l: We beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The ſea and wind ſtrove who ſhould moſt befriend us,
And as they favourd our deſigne and lov'd us,
So lead us forth—where lies the boat that brought us?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Safe lodg'd within the Reeds, cloſe by the Caſtle,
That no eye can ſuſpect, nor thought come neare it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But where have you been, brave ſir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have broke the Ice boyes:
I have begun the game, faire fortune guide it,
Suſpectleſſe have I travell'd all the towne through,
And in this Merchants ſhape won much acquaintance,
Survey'd each ſtrength and place that may befriend us,
View'd all his Magazines, got perfect knowledge
Of where the priſon is, and what power guards it.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Theſe will be ſtrong attempts.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Courage is ſtrong:
What we began with policy, my deare friends,
Let's end with manly force; there's no retiring,
Unleſſe it be with ſhame.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Shame his that hopes it

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Better a few, and clearer fame will follow us,
However, loſe or win, and ſpeak our memories,
Then if we led our Armies; things done thus,
And of this noble waight, will ſtile us worthyes.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Direct, and we have done, bring us to execute,
And if we flinch, or faile—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I am ſure ye dare not.
Then further know, and let no eare be neare us
That may be falſe.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Speak boldly on, we are honeſt;
Our lives and fortunes yours.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hard by the place then
Where all his treaſure lies, his armes, his women,
Cloſe by the priſon too where he keeps the King,
I have hir'd a lodging, as a trading merchant,
A Celler to that too, to ſtow my wares in,
The very wall of which, joynes to his ſtore-houſe.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: What of all this?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye are dull, if ye apprehend not:
Into that Celler, elected friends, I have convey'd
And unſuſpected too that will doe it;
That that will make all ſhake, and ſmoak too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My thoughts have not been idle, nor my practice:
The fire I brought here with me ſhall doe ſomething,
Shall burſt into materiall flames, and bright ones,
That all the Iſland ſhall ſtand wondring at it,
As if they had been ſtricken with a Comet:
Powder is ready, and enough to worke it,
The match is left a-fire, all, all huſht, and lockt cloſe,
No man ſuſpecting what I am but Merchant:
An houre hence, my brave friends, look for the fury,
The fire to light us to our honour'd purpoſe,
For by that time 'twill take.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: What are our duties?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: When all are full of feare and fright, the Governour
Out of his wits, the to ſee flames ſo imperious,
Ready to turne to aſhes all he worſhips,
And all the people there to ſtop theſe ruines,
No man regarding any private office;
Then flie we to the priſon ſuddenly,
Here's one has found the way, and dares direct us.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then to our ſwords and good hearts,
I long for it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Certaine we ſhall not find much oppoſition,
But what is muſt be forced.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely caſt ſir,
And ſurely too I hope.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: If the fire faile not,
And powder hold his nature, ſome muſt preſently
Upon the firſt cry of the amazed people,
(For nothing will be markt then, but the miſerie)
Be ready with the boat upon an inſtant,
And then all's right and faire.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Bleſſe us deare fortune.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Let us be worthie of it in our courage,
And fortune muſt befriend us, come all ſever,
But keep ſtill within fight, when the flame riſes
Let's meet, and either doe, or dye.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: So be it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No Captaine, for thoſe troops we need 'em not,
The Towne is ſtrong enough to ſtand their furies;
I wou'd ſee 'em come, and offer to doe ſomething.
They are high in words.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: 'Tis ſafer ſir then doing.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Doſt thinke they dare attempt.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: May be by treaty
But ſure by force they wil not prove ſo forward.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No faith, I warrant thee, they know me wel enough,
And know they have no child in hand to play with:
They know my nature too, I have bit ſome of 'em,
And to the bones, they have reaſon to remember me,
It makes me laugh to think how glorious
The fooles are in their promiſes, and how pregnant
Their wits and powers are to bring things to paſſe;
Am I not growne leane with loſſe of ſleep and care
To prevent theſe threatnings, Captaine?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: You look well ſir:
Upon my conſcience you are not like to ſicken
Upon any ſuch conceit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall not:
Well wou'd I had this wench, for I muſt have her,
She muſt be mine; and there's another charge Captaine;
What betwixt love and brawling I got nothing,
All goes in maintenance—
Heark what was that, The Train takes.
That noyſe there? it went with a violence.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Some old wall belike ſir,
That had no neighbour helpe to hold it up,
Is fallen ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Gov,
sp.l: I muſt diſcard theſe Raſcals,
That are not able to maintaine their buildings,
They blur the beauty of the Town.

sp.speaker: Within,
sp.l: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I heare another tune, good Captaine,
It comes on freſher ſtill, tis loud and fearefull,
Look up into the Towne, how bright the ayre ſhewes;
Upon my life ſome ſuddaine fire. Ex. Cap.
The bell too? Bell Rings.
I heare the noyſe more cleare

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Suddenly taken in a Merchans houſe ſir,
Fearefull and high it blazes; helpe good people.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Pox o'their paper-houſes, how they ſmother,
They light like candles, how the rore ſtill riſes?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Your Magazine's a fire ſir, help, help ſuddenly,
The Caſtle too is in danger, in much danger,
All will be loſt, get the people preſently,
And all that are your guard, and all helpe, all hands ſir,
Your wealth, your ſtrenth, is burnt elſe, the town periſht;
The Caſtle now begins to flame.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: My ſoule ſhakes.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A Merchants houſe next joyning? ſhame light on him,
That ever ſuch a neighbour, ſuch a villaine—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Raiſe all the garriſon, and bring 'em up.
And beat the people forward—Oh I have loſt all
In one houſe, all my hopes: good worthy Citizens
Follow me all, and all your powers give to me,
I will reward you all. Oh curſed fortune—
The flame's more violent: ariſe ſtill, help, helpe Citizens,
Freedome & wealth to him that helps: follow, oh follow.
Fling wine, or any thing, Ile ſee't recompenc'd.
Buckets, more Buckets; fire, fire, fire. Ex. omnes.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Let it flame on, a comely light it gives up
To our diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Hearke, what a merry crye
Theſe hounds make? forward fairely,
We are not ſeen in the miſt, we are Not noted. Away,
Away. Now if we loſe our fortune — Exit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Up ſouldiers, up, and deale like men.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: More water, more water, all is conſum'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: All's gone, unleſſe you undertake it ſtraight, your
Wealth too, that muſt preſerve, & pay your labor bravely.
Up, up, away. Ex. Cap. and Cit. Then,

div.stage: Enter Armuſia and his company breaking open a doore.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: So, thou art open, keep the way cleare
Behinde ſtill. Now for the place.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: 'Tis here ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sure this is it.
Force ope the doore—A miſerable creature!
Yet by his manly face — The King diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why ſtare ye on me?
You cannot put on faces to afright me:
In death I am a King ſtill, and contemne ye:
Where is that Governour? me thinks his man-hood
Should be well pleas'd to ſee my Tragedy,
And come to bath his ſterne eyes in my ſorrowes;
I dare him to the fight, bring his ſcornes with him,
And all his rugged threats: here's a throat, ſouldiers;
Come, ſee who can ſtrike deepeſt.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Break the Chain there.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What does this mean?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Come, talke of no more Governours,
He has other buſineſſe ſir, put your legs forward,
And gather up your courage like a man,
Wee'll carrie off your head elſe: we are friends,
And come to give your ſorrowes eaſe.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: On bravely;
Delayes may loſe agen,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The Guard.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Make ſpeedy, and ſure work.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: They flye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Up with him, and to the Boat; ſtand faſt, now be ſpeedy,
When this heat's paſt, wee'll ſing our Hiſtory.
Away, like thoughts, ſudden as deſires, friends;
Now ſacred chance be ours.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Pray when we have done ſir.
What is the fire allaid?
'Tis out, tis out,
Or paſt the worſt, I never did ſo ſtoutly
I'le aſſure you neighbours ſince I was a man:
I have been burnt at both ends like a ſquib:
I liv'd two hovres in the fire, 'twas a hideous matter;
But when men of underſtanding come about it,
Men that judge of things, my wife gave me over,
And tooke her leave a hundred times, I bore up ſtill,
And toſt the Buckets boyes.
We are all meere Martins.
I heard a voice at latter end o'th hurry,
Or elſe I dreamt I heard it, that ſaid treaſon.
'Tis like enough, it might cry murder to, for there was
Many without a joint, but whats that to us: Lets home
And fright our wives. for we looke like Devils.
Here come ſome of 'em to fright us.

sp.speaker: 1 W.
sp.l: Mine's alive neighbor— oh ſweet hony husband.
Thou lieſt I thinke abominably, and thou hadſt bin
In my place, thou wouldſt have ſtunke at both ends.
Get me ſome drinke, give me whole tuns of drinke,
Whole ciſternes, for I have foure dozen of fine firebrands
In my belly, I have more ſmoke in my mouth, then would
Blote a hundred herrings.

sp.speaker: 2 Wo.
sp.l: Art thou come ſafe agen?

sp.speaker: 3 Wo.
sp.l: I pray you what became of my man, is he in a wel?
At hearts eaſe in a Well, is very well neighbour;
We left him drinking of a new dozen of Buckets;
Thy husbands happy, he was through roaſted,
And now hee's baſting of himſelfe at all points:
The Clarke and he are cooling their pericraniums;
Body O me neighbors there's fire in my codpiece.

sp.speaker: 1 Wo.
sp.l: Bleſſe my husband.
Blow it out wife—blow, blow, the gable end a'th' ſtore-houſe.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.l: Some water, water, water.
Peace, tis but a ſparkle;
Raiſe not the Towne again, 'twill be a great hinderance,
I'm glad tis out, and 't had tane in my hayloft?
What frights are theſe, marry heaven bleſſe thy modicum.

sp.speaker: 3 Wo.
sp.l: But is a drown'd outright, pray put me out of Feare neighbor.
Thou wouldſt have it ſo, but after a hundred fires
More, hee'l live to ſee thee burnt for brewing muſty Liquor.
Come lets goe neighbor.
For I would very faine turne downe this liquor;
Come, come, I fry like a burnt marry-bone:
Women get you afore, and draw upon us;
Run wenches run, and let your taps run with ye;
Run as the fire were in your tailes, cry ale, ale.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Away lets nouriſh the poore wretches.
Wee'l Rallie up the reſt of the burnt Regiment.

div.stage: Enter Governor, Captaine, Souldier, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: The fire's quencht Captain, but the miſchief hangs ſtill;
The Kings redeem'd, & gon too; a trick, a dam'd one:
Oh I am overtaken poorely, tamely.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Where were the guard that waited upon the priſon?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Moſt of 'em ſlaine, yet ſome ſcap't ſir, and they deliver,
They ſaw a little boat ready to receive him,
And thoſe redeem'd him, making ſuch haſte and fighting;
Fighting beyond the force of men.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am loſt Captaine,
And all the world will laugh at this, and ſcorne me:
Count me a heavy ſleepy foole, a coward,
A coward paſt recovery, a confirm'd coward,
One without carriage, or common ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Hee's gone ſir,
And put to ſea amaine, paſt our recovery,
Not a Boat ready to purſue; if there were any,
The people ſtand amazed ſo at their valour,
And the ſudden fright of fire, none knowes to execute.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Oh, I could tear my limbs, & knock my boys brains
'Gainſt every poſt I meet; fool'd with a fire?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It was a crafty trick.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: No, I was lazy,
Confident ſluggiſh lazie, had I but met 'em,
And chang'd a dozen blowes, I had forgiv'n 'em,
By both theſe hands held up, and by that brightneſſe
That gildes the worldwith light, by all our worſhips,
The hidden ebbes and flowes of the blew Ocean,
I will not reſt; no mirth ſhall dwell upon me,
Wine touch my mouth, nor any thing refreſh me,
Till I be wholy quit of this diſhonour:
Make ready my Barrato's inſtantly,
And what I ſhall intend—

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: We are your ſervants. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Never tell me, you never car'd to win me,
Never for my ſake to attempt a deed,
Might draw me to a thought you ſought my favour:
If not for love of me, for love of armes ſir,
For that cauſe you profeſſe, for love of honour,
Of which you ſtile your ſelfe the mighty Maſter,
You might have ſtept out nobly, and made an offer,
As if you had intended ſomething excellent,
Put on a forward face.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Deare Lady hold me—

sp.speaker: Quiſar,
sp.l: I hold ye, as I finde yee, a faint ſervant.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: By—I dare doe—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: In a Ladies chamber
I dare beleeve ye, there's no mortall danger:
Give me the man that dares doe, to deſerve that:
I thought you Portugalls had been rare wonders,
Men of thoſe haughty courages and credits,
That all things were confin'd within your promiſes,
The Lords of fate and fortune I beleev'd yee,
But well I ſee I am deceiv'd Ruy Dias,
And blame too late my much beliefe.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I am aſham'd, Lady,
I was ſo dull, ſo ſtupid to your offer:
Now you have once more ſchool'd me, I am right,
And ſomething ſhall be thought on ſuddenly,
And put in act as ſoone, ſome preparation —

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: And give it out?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Yes, Lady, and ſo great too:
In which, the noyſe of all my Countrey-men—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Thoſe will doe well, for they are all approv'd ones,
And though he be reſtor'd alive.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I have ye.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: For then we are both ſervants.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I conceive ye,
Good Madam give me leave to turne my fancies.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.p: Do, & make all things fit, & then Ile viſit you. Ex.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: My ſelfe, the cozen, and the Garriſon,
The neighbours of the out-Iſles of our nation,
Syana's ſtrength, for I can humour him:
And proud Bekamus, I ſhall deceive his glory. A ſhout.
What ringing ſound of joy is this? whence comes it?
May be the Princes are in ſport.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Where are ye?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Now Pyniero, what's the haſte you ſeek me?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Doe you know this ſigne ſir?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Doe you know this embleme?
Your noſe is boar'd.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Boar'd? what's that?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Y'are topt ſir:
The Kings come home againe, the King.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: The devill?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay ſure he came a gods name home:
Hee's return'd ſir.

sp.speaker: Chriſt.
sp.l: And all this joy yee heare—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Who durſt attempt him?
The Princes are all here.

sp.speaker: Chry.
sp.l: They are worthy Princes,
They are ſpeciall Princes, all they love by ounces.
Believe it ſir, 'tis done, and done moſt bravely and eaſily.
What fortune have ye loſt ſir?
What juſtice have ye now unto this Lady?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How ſtands your claime?
That ever man ſhould be fool'd ſo,
When he ſhould doe and proſper; ſtand proteſting,
Kiſſing the hand, and farting for a favour,
When he ſhould be about his buſineſſe ſweating;
She bid you goe, and pickt you out a purpoſe,
To make your ſelfe a fortune by, a Lady, a Lady, and a luſty one,
A lovely, that now you may goe look, ſhe poynted ye,
Knowing you were a man of worth and merit,
And bid you fly, you have made a faire flight on't,
You have caught a gooſe.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: How dare you thus moleſt me? A ſhout.
It cannot bee.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Heark how the generall joy rings!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Have you your hearing left? is not that drunk too?
For if you had been ſober, you had been wiſe ſure.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Done? who dares doe?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It ſeems an honeſt fellow,
That has ended his Market before you be up.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: The ſhame on't 's a ſtranger too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: 'Tis no ſhame,
He took her at her word, and tyed the bargaine,
Dealt like a man indeed, ſtood not demurring,
But clapt cloſe to the cauſe, as he will doe to the Lady:
'Is a fellow of that ſpeed and handſomneſſe,
He will get her with childe too, ere you ſhall come to know him,
Is it not brave, a gentleman ſcarce landed,
Scarce eating of the aire here, not acquainted,
No circumſtance of love depending on him,
Nor no command to ſhew him, muſt ſtart forth,
At the firſt ſight to—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Like an Oyſter:
She neither taking view, nor value of him,
Unto ſuch deeds as theſe — Pox o'theſe,
Theſe wiſe delayings—
They make men cowards.
You are undone as a man would undoe an egge,
A hundred ſhames about ye.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Can it be poſſible,
A ſtanger that I have not knowne, not ſeen yet,
A man I never grac'd; O Captaine, Captaine,
What ſhall I doe? I am betray'd by fortune,
It cannot be, it muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: It is Lady,
And by my faith a hanſome Gentleman;
'Tis his poore Schollers prize.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Muſt I be given
Unto a man I never ſaw, ne're ſpoke with,
I know not of what Nation?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Is a Portugall,
And of as good a pitch he will be given to you Lady,
For hee's given much to hanſome fleſh.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Oh Ruy Dias,
This was your ſloth, your ſloth, your ſloth Ruy Dias.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Your love ſloth, Unckle doe you find it now?
You ſhould have done at firſt, and faithfully: A ſhout.
And then the tother had lyed ready for ye;
Madam, the generall joy comes.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: We muſt meet it—but with what comfort?

div.stage: Enter Citizens carrying boughes, boyes ſinging after 'em; Then King, Armuſia, Soza, Emannuell; The Princes and traine following.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Oh my deare brother what a joy runs through me,
To ſee you ſafe again, your ſelfe, and mighty,
What a bleſt day is this?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Riſe up faire ſiſter,
I am not welcome till you have embraced me.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A generall gladnes ſir flies through the City,
And mirth poſſeſſes all to ſee your Grace arrive,
Thus happily arrived againe, and fairely;
'Twas a brave venture who ſo e're put for it,
A high and noble one, worthy much honor;
And had it failed, we had not failed great ſir,
And in ſhort time too to have forc'd the Governor,
In ſpight of all his threats.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I thanke ye Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: And all his ſubtilties to ſet you free,
With all his heart and will too.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I know ye love me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This had bin good with ſomething done before it,
Somthing ſet off to beautifie it, now it ſounds emptie like
A Barbers baſon, pox there's no mettall in't, no noble marrow.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I have an army ſir, but that the Governor,
The fooliſh fellow was a little provident,
And wiſe in letting ſlip no time, became him too,
That would have ſcoured him elſe, and all his confines;
That would have rung him ſuch a peale —

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes backward,
To make doggs houle, I know thee to a farthing,
Thy armye's good for hawkes, there's
Nothing but ſheeps hearts in it.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: I have done nothing ſir, therefore
I thinke it convenient I ſay little what I purpoſed,
And what my love intended.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I like your modeſtie,
And thanke ye royall friends, I know it griev'd ye
To know my miſerie; but this man Princes,
I muſt thanke heartily indeed and truly,
For this man ſaw me in't, and redeemed me:
He lookt upon me ſinking, and then caught me.
This ſiſter this, this all man, this all valour,
This pious man.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: My countenance, it ſhames me,
One ſcarce arrived, not harden'd yet, not
Read in dangers and great deeds, ſea-ſick, not ſeaſon'd —
Oh I have boy'd my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: This noble bulwarke,
This launce and honor of our age and Kingdome;
This that I never can reward, nor hope
To be once worthy of the name of friend to,
This, this man from the bowels of my ſorrowes
Has new begot my name, and once more made me:
Oh ſiſter, if there may be thanks for this,
Or any thing neere recompence invented.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You are too noble ſir, there is reward
Above my action too by millions:
A recompence ſo rich and glorious,
I durſt not dreame it mine, but that 'twas promiſed;
But that it was propounded, ſworne and ſealed
Before the face of heaven, I durſt not hope it,
For nothing in the life of man, or merit,
It is ſo truly great, can elſe embrace it.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: O ſpeake it, ſpeake it, bleſſe mine eares to heare it,
Make me a happy man, to know it may be,
For ſtill methinkes I am a priſoner,
And feele no libertie before I find it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Then know it is your ſiſter, ſhe is mine ſir,
I claime her by her owne word, and her honour;
It was her open promiſe to that man
That durſt redeeme ye; Beauty ſet me on,
And fortune crownes me faire, if ſhe receive me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Receive ye ſir — why ſiſter — ha — ſo backward,
Stand as you knew me not, nor what he has ventured
My deareſt ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good ſir pardon me,
There is a bluſhing modeſtie becomes her,
That holds her back; women are nice to wooe ſir;
I would not have her forced, give her faire libertie;
For things compell'd and frighted of ſoft natures,
Turne into feares, and flye from their owne wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Looke on my Quiſara ſuch another,
Oh all ye powers, ſo excellent in nature,
In honour ſo abundant.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I confeſſe ſir,
Confeſſe my word is paſt too, he has purchaſed;
Yet good ſir give me leave to thinke, but time
To be acquainted with his worth and perſon;
To make me fit to know it; we are both ſtrangers,
And how we ſhould beleeve ſo ſuddenly,
Or come to faſten our affections —
Alas, love has his complements.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Be ſudden
And certaine in your way, no womans doubles,
Nor coy delayes, you are his, and ſo aſſure it,
Or caſt from me and my remembrance ever;
Reſpect your word, I know you will, come ſiſter,
Lets ſee what welcome you can give a priſoner,
And what faire lookes a friend — Oh my moſt noble
Princes, no diſcontents, but all be luſtie,
He that frownes this day is an open enemie:
Thus in my armes my deare.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You make me bluſh ſir.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: And now lead on —
Our whole Court crowned with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Madam, deſpaire not, ſomething ſhall be done yet,
And ſuddenly and wiſely.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: O Ruy Dias. Ex.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well he's a brave fellow, & he has deſerv'd her richly,
And you have had your hands full I dare ſwear Gentlemē.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: We have done ſomething ſir, if it hit right.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: The woman has no eyes elſe, nor no honeſty,
So much I think.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come, let's goe bounce amongſt 'em,
To the Kings health, and my brave country-mans.
My uncle looks as though he were ſick oth'
Worms friends. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.l: MIne uncle haunts me up & down, looks melancholy,
Then whiſtles, ſtarts, cries, & groans, as if he had the Bots.
As to ſay truth, I think h'as little better,
And wo'd fain ſpeak; bids me good morrow at midnight,
And good night when 'tis noon, has ſomething hovers
About his braines, that would faine finde an iſſue,
But cannot out, or dares not: ſtil he followes; Enter Ruy Dyas.
How he looks ſtill, and how he beats about,
Like an old Dog at a dead ſent? I marry,
There was a ſigh wou'd a ſet a ſhip a ſayling:
Theſe winds of love and honour blow at all ends.
Now ſpeak and't be thy will: good morrow Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Good morrow ſir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is a new ſalute:
Sure h'as forgot me: this is pur-blinde Cupid.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: My Nephew?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes ſir, it I be not chang'd.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I wou'd faine ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I wou'd faine have ye ſir,
For to that end I ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You know I love yee,
And I have lov'd you long, my deare Pyniero,
Bred and ſupply'd you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Whither walks this Preamble?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You may remember, though I am but your Uncle,
I ſure had a fathers care, a fathers tenderneſſe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Sure he would wrap me into ſomething now ſuddenly,
He doubts my nature in, for mine is honeſt,
He windes about me ſo.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A fathers deligence.
My privat benefits, I have forgot ſir,
But thoſe you might lay claime to as my follower;
Yet ſome men wou'd remember—

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I doe dayly.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: The place which I have put ye in, which is no weak one,
Next to my ſelfe you ſtand in all employments,
Your counſells, cares, aſſignements with me equall,
So is my ſtudy ſtill to plant your perſon;
Theſe are ſmall teſtimonies I have not forgot ye,
Nor wou'd not be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Sure you cannot.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: O Pyniero—

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Sir; what hangs upon you,
What heavy weight oppreſſes ye, ye have loſt,
(I muſt confeſſe, in thoſe that underſtand ye)
Some little of your credit, but time will cure that;
The beſt may ſlip ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Oh my beſt Nephew—

sp.speaker: Pyn
sp.l: It may be yee feare her too, that diſturbs ye,
That ſhe may fall her ſelfe, or be forc'd from ye.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: She is ever true, but I undone for ever.
Oh that Armuſia, that new thing, that ſtranger,
That flag ſtuck up to rob me of mine honor;
That murdring chaine ſhot at me from my Country;
That goodly plague that I muſt court to kill me.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Now it comes flowing from him, I feared this,
Knew, he that durſt be idle, durſt be ill too,
Has he not done a brave thing?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe it nephew, muſt allow it,
But that brave thing has undone me, has ſunke me,
Has trod me like a name in ſand to nothing,
Hangs betwixt hope and me, and threatens my ruine:
And if he riſe and blaze, farewell my fortune;
And when thats ſet, where's thy advancement Cozen?
That were a friend, that were a noble kinſman,
That would conſider theſe; that man were gratefull;
And he that durſt doe ſomething here durſt love me.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: You ſay true, 'tis worth conſideration,
Your reaſons are of weight, and marke me Unckle,
For I'le be ſudden, and to'th' purpoſe with you.
Say this Armuſia then wert taken off,
As it may be eaſily done
How ſtands the woman?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: She is mine for ever;
For ſhe contemnes his deed and him.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Pox on him,
Or if the ſingle pox be not ſufficient,
The hogs, the dogs, and devils pox poſſeſſe him:
'Faith this Armuſia ſtumbles me, is a brave fellow;
And if he could be ſpared Unckle—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I muſt periſh:
Had he ſet up at any reſt but this,
Done any thing but what concern'd my credit,
The everlaſting loſing of my worth.—

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I underſtand you now, who ſet you on too;
I had a reaſonable good opinion of the devill
Till this houre; and I ſee he is a knave indeed,
An arrant ſtinking knave, for now I ſmell him;
I'le ſee what may be done then, you ſhall know
You have a kinſman, but no villaine Unckle,
Nor no betrayer of faire fame, I ſcorne it;
I love and honour vertue; I muſt have
Acceſſe unto the Lady to know her mind too,
A good word from her mouth you know may ſtir me;
A Ladies looke at ſetting on—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You ſay well;
Here Cozen, here's a Letter readie for you,
And you ſhall ſee how nobly ſhee'l receive you,
And with what care direct.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Farewell then Unckle,
After I have talked with her, I am your ſervant,
To make you honeſt if I can — elſe hate you.
Pray ye no more complements, my head is buſie, heaven bleſſe me;
What a malicious ſoule does this man carry?
And to what ſcurvy things this love converts us?
What ſtinking things, and how ſweetly they become us?
Murther's a morall vertue with theſe Lovers,
A ſpeciall peece of Divinitie I take it:
I may be mad, or violentlie drunke,
Which is a whelp of that litter; or I may be covetous,
And learne to murther mens eſtates, thats baſe too;
Or proud, but thats a Paradiſe to this;
Or envious, and ſit eating of my ſelfe
At others fortunes; I may lye, and damnably,
Beyond the patience of an honeſt hearer;
Couzen, Cut purſes, ſit i'th' ſtocks for apples.
But when I am a lover, Lord have mercy,
Theſe are poore pelting ſins, or rather plagues,
Love and Ambition draw the devills Coach.
How now! who are theſe? Oh my great Ladies followers,
Her riddle-founders, and her fortune-tellers,
Her readers of her love-lectures, her inflamers:
Theſe doors I muſt paſſe through, I hope they are wide.
Good day to your beauties, how they take it to 'em?
As if they were faire indeed.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: Good morrow to you ſir.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: That's the old Hen, the brood-bird? how ſhe buſies?
How like an Inventory of Lecherie ſhe looks?
Many a good peece of iniquity
Has paſt her hands, I warrant her—I beſeech you,
Is the faire Princeſſe ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes marry is ſhe ſir,
But ſomewhat private: have you a buſineſſe with her?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Yes forſooth have I, and a ſerious buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: May not we know?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Yes, when you can keep counſell.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How prettily he looks? he's a ſouldier ſure,
His rudeneſſe ſits ſo handſomly upon him.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: A good blunt gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Yes marry am I:
Yet for a puſh or two at ſharp, an't pleaſe you —

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My honeſt friend, you know not who you ſpeak to:
This is the Princeſſe Aunt.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I like her th' better
And ſhe were her Mother, (Lady) or her grandmother,
I am not ſo baſhfull but I can buckle with her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Of what ſize is your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Of the long ſixteens,
And will make way I warrant yee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How fine he talks?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Nay in troth I talke but courſely, Lady,
But I hold it comfortable for the underſtanding:
How faine they won'd draw me into ribaldry?
Theſe wenches that live eaſily, live high,
And love theſe broad diſcourſes, as they love poſſets;
Theſe dry delights ſerve for preparatives.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why doe you look ſo on me?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I am gheſſing
By the caſt of your face, what the property of your place ſhould be,
For I preſume you turne a key ſweet beauty,
And you another gravity, under the Princeſſe,
And by my — I warrant ye good places,
Comely commodious feates.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: Prethee let him talke ſtill,
For me thinkes he talkes hanſomely.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And truly
As neare as my underſtanding ſhall enable me
You look as if you kept my Ladies ſecrets:
Nay doe not laugh, for I meane honeſtly,
How theſe young things tattle, when they get a toy by th' end?
And how their hearts goe pit a pat and look for it?
Wou'd it not dance too, if it had a Fiddle?
Your gravity I gheſſe, to take the Petitions,
And heare the lingring ſuits in love diſpos'd,
Their ſighes and ſorrowes in their proper place,
You keep the ayme office.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Prethee ſuffer him,
For as I live hee's a pretty fellow.
I love to here ſometimes what men think of us:
And thus deliver'd freely, 'tis no malice:
Proceed good honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I will, good Madam.
According to mens ſtates and dignities,
Moneyes and moveables, you rate their dreames,
And caſt the Nativity of their deſires,
If he reward well, all he thinks is proſperous:
And if he promiſe place, his dreams are Oracles;
Your ancient practique Art too in theſe diſcoveries,
Who loves at ſuch a length, who a ſpan farther,
And who drawes home, yeeld you no little profit,
For theſe yee milk by circumſtance.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Yee are cunning.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: And as they Oyle ye, and advance your ſpindle,
So you draw out the lines of love, your doores too,
The doores of deſtiny, that men muſt paſſe through;
Theſe are faire places.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He knowes all.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Your trap doores,
To pop fooles in it, that have no providence,
Your litle wickets, to work wiſe men, like wires throgh at,
And draw their ſtates and bodies into Cobwebs,
Your Poſterne doores, to catch thoſe that are cautelous,
And would not have the worlds eye finde their knaveries:
Your doores of danger, ſome men hate a pleaſure,
Unleſſe that may be full of feares; your hope doores,
And thoſe are fine commodities, where fooles pay
For every new encouragement, a new cuſtome;
You have your doores of honour, and of pleaſure;
But thoſe are for great Princes, glorious vanities,
That travell to be famous through diſeaſes;
There be the doores of povertie and death too:
But theſe you doe the beſt you can to damme up,
For then your gaine goes out.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: This is a rare lecture.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Read to them that underſtand.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Beſhrew me,
I dare not venture on ye, yee cut too keen ſir.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: We thank you ſir for your good mirth Enter Quiſara
You are a good Companion.
Here comes the Princeſſe now, attend your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Is there no remedy? no hopes can help me?
No wit to ſet me free? whoſe there hoe?

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: Troubled? her looks are almoſt wilde:
What ailes the Princeſſe?
I know nothing ſhe wants.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Who's that there with you?
Oh Signeur Piniero? you are moſt welcome:
How does your noble uncle?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: Sad as you are Madam:
But he commends his ſervice, and this Letter.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Goe off, attend within—Faire ſir, I thank ye,
Pray be no ſtranger, for indeed you are welcome;
For your owne vertues welcome.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: We are miſtaken,
This is ſome brave fellow ſure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I'me ſure hee's a bold fellow:
But if ſhe hold him ſo, we muſt beleeve it. Ex.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Doe you know of this faire ſir?

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: I gheſſe it Madam,
And whither it intends: I had not brought it elſe.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: It is a buſineſſe of no common reckoning.

sp.speaker: Pin.
sp.l: The handſomer for him that goes about it;
Slight actions are rewarded with ſlight thanks:
Give me a matter of ſome waight to wade in.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: And can you love your Uncle ſo directly,
So ſeriouſly, and ſo full, to undertake this?
Can there be ſuch a faith?

sp.speaker: Pyn:
sp.l: Dare you ſay I to it,
And ſet me on? 'tis no matter for my Uncle,
Or what I owe to him, dare you but wiſh it.

sp.speaker: Ouiſar.
sp.l: I wou'd faine—

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Have it done; ſay but ſo Lady.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: Conceive it ſo.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I will, 'tis that I am bound too:
Your will that muſt command me, and your pleaſure,
The faire aſpects of thoſe eyes, that muſt direct me:
I am no Uncles agent, I am mine owne, Lady;
I ſcorne my able youth ſhould plough for others,
Or my ambition ſerve for pay; I ayme,
Although I never hit, as high as any man,
And the reward I reach at ſhall be equall,
And what love ſpurs me on to, this deſire,
Makes me forget an honeſt man, a brave man,
A valiant, and a vertuous man, my country-man, Armuſia,
The delight of all the Minions,
Is love of you, doting upon your beauty, the admiration of your excellence;
Make me but ſervant to the pooreſt ſmile,
Or the leaſt grace you have beſtow'd on others,
And ſee how ſuddenly Ile worke your ſafety,
And ſet your thoughts at peace; I am no flatterer,
To promiſe infinitely, and out-dream dangers;
To lye a bed, and ſweare men into Feavers,
Like ſome of your trim ſuters; when I promiſe,
The light is not more conſtant to the world,
Then I am to my word — She turnes for millions.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I have not ſeen a braver confirm'd courage.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: For a tun of Crownes ſhe turns: ſhe is a woman,
And much I feare a worſe then I expected.
You are the object Lady, you are the eye
In which all excellence appears, all wonder,
From which all hearts take fire, all hands their valour:
And when he ſtands diſputing, when you bid him,
Or but thinks of his eſtate, Father, Mother,
Friends, Wife, and Children,
'Is a foole, and I ſcorne him,
And be but to make cleane his ſword: coward
Men have forgot their fealty to beauty.
Had I the place in your affections,
My moſt unworthy uncle is fit to fall from,
Liv'd in thoſe bleſſed eyes, and read the ſtories
Of everlaſting pleaſures figur'd there,
I wou'd finde out your cōmands before you thought 'em,
And bring 'em to you done, ere you dream't of 'em.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: I admire his boldneſſe.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: This, or any thing;
Your brothers death, mine uncles, any mans,
No ſtate that ſtands ſecure, if you frowne on it.
Look on my youth, I bring no blaſtings to you,
The firſt flower of my ſtrength, my faith.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: No more ſir;
I am too willing to believe, reſt ſatisfi'd;
If you dare doe for me, I ſhall be thankfull:
You are a handſome gentleman, a faire one,
My ſervant if you pleaſe; I feale it thus ſir.
No more, till you deſerve more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: I am rewarded:
This woman's cunning, but ſhe's bloudy too;
Although ſhe pulls her Tallons in, ſhe's miſchievous;
Form'd like the face of heaven, cleare and tranſparent;
I muſt pretend ſtill, beare 'em both in hopes,
For feare ſome bloudy ſlave thruſt in indeed,
Faſhion'd and fleſh'd to what they wiſh: well uncle,
What will become of this, and what diſhonour
Follow this fatall ſhaft, if ſhot, let time tell,
I can but only feare, and croſſe to croſſe it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why are you thus ſad? what can grieve or vex you
That have the pleaſures of the world, the profits,
The honour, and the loves at your diſpoſes?
Why ſhould a man that wants nothing, want his quiet?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I want what beggars are above me in, content:
I want the grace I have merited,
The favour, the due reſpect.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Does not the King allow it?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes and all honors elſe, all I can aske,
That he has power to give; but from his ſiſter,
The ſcornfull crueltie, forgive me beauty,
That I tranſgreſſe from her that ſhould looke on me,
That ſhould a little ſmile upon my ſervice,
And foſter my deſerts for her owne faiths ſake;
That ſhould at leaſt acknowledge me, ſpeake to me.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: And you goe whining up and downe for this ſir,
Lamenting and diſputing of your grievances;
Sighing and ſobbing like a ſullen Schoole-boy,
And curſing good-wife fortune for this favor.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What would you have me doe?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Doe what you ſhould doe,
What a man would doe in this caſe, a wiſe man,
An underſtanding man that knowes a woman;
Knowes her and all her tricks, her ſcorns & all her trifles:
Goe to her and take her in your armes and ſhake her,
Take her and toſſe her like a barre.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But be ſure you pitch her upon a feather-bed,
Shake her between a paire of ſheets ſir,
There ſhake theſe ſullen fits out of her, ſpare her not there,
There you may breake her will, and bruiſe no bone ſir.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Goe to her.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Thats the way.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: And tell her and boldly,
And doe not mince the matter, nor mocke your ſelfe,
With being too indulgent to her pride:
Let her heare roundly from ye, what ye are,
And what ye haue deſerved, and what ſhe muſt be.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And be not put off like a common fellow,
With the Princeſſe would be private,
Or that ſhe has taken phiſicke, and admits none,
I would talke to her any where.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It makes me ſmile.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now you looke hanſomely:
Had I a wench to win, I would ſo flutter her,
They love a man that cruſhes 'em to verjuice;
A woman held at hard meat is your ſpanniel.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Pray take our counſell ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I ſhall doe ſomething,
But not your way, it ſhewes too boiſterous,
For my affections are as faire and gentle,
As her they ſerve. Enter King.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Why, how now friend?
Why doe you rob me of the companie
I love ſo dearly ſir, I have bin ſeeking you;
For when I want you, I want all my pleaſure:
Why ſad? thus ſad ſtill man; I will not have it;
I muſt not ſee the face I love thus ſhadowed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And't pleaſe your Grace, methinks it ill becomes him,
A ſouldier ſhould be joviall, high and luſtie.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He ſhall be ſo, come, come, I know your reaſon,
It ſhall be none to croſſe you, ye ſhall have her,
Take my word, ('tis a Kings word) ye ſhall have her,
She ſhall be yours or nothing, pray be merry.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Your grace has given me cauſe, I ſhall be ſir,
And ever your poore ſervant.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Me my ſelfe ſir,
My better ſelfe, I ſhall finde time, and ſuddenly,
To gratifie your loves too gentlemen,
And make you know how much I ſtand bound to you:
Nay 'tis not worth your thanks, no further complement;
Will you goe with me friend?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I beſeech your grace,
Spare me an houre or two, I ſhall wait on you,
Some little private buſineſſe with my ſelfe ſir,
For ſuch a time.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ile hinder no devotion,
For I know you are regular, Ile take you gentlemen,
Becauſe hee ſhall have nothing to diſturbe him,
I ſhall look for your friend. Exeunt. Manet Armuſia.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I dare not faile ſir: Enter Panura.
What ſhal I doe to make her know my miſery,
To make her ſenſible? This is her woman,
I have a toy come to me ſuddenly,
It may worke for the beſt, ſhe can but ſcorne me,
And lower then I am I cannot tumble,
Ile trye what ere my fate be—Good even faire one,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis the brave ſtranger—A good night to you ſir.
Now by my Ladies hand a goodly gentleman!
How happy ſhall ſhe be in ſuch a husband?
Wou'd I were ſo provided too.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Good pretty one,
Shall I keep you company for an houre or two?
I want employment for this evening.
I am an honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I dare beleeve yee:
Or if yee were not ſir, that's no great matter,
We take mens promiſes, wou'd ye ſtay with me ſir?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: So it pleaſe you; pray let's be better acquainted,
I know you are the Princeſſe gentlewoman,
And wait upon her neere.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis like I doe ſo.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: And may befriend a man, do him faire courteſies,
If he have buſineſſe your way.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I underſtand yee.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: So kinde an office, that you may bind a gentleman
Hereafter to be yours, and your way too,
And ye may bleſſe the houre you did this benefit,
Sweet handſome faces ſhould have courteous mindes,
And ready faculties.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Tell me your buſineſſe,
Yet if I thinke it be to her, your ſelfe ſir,
For I know what you are, and what we hold ye,
And in what grace ye ſtand, without a ſecond
For that but darkens, you wou'd doe it better,
The Princeſſe muſt be pleas'd with your acceſſes,
I'me ſure I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I want a Courtiers boldneſſe,
And am yet but a ſtranger, I wou'd faine ſpeak with her:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis very late, and upon her houre of ſleep ſir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Pray ye weare this, and believe my meaning civil,
My buſineſſe of that faire reſpect and carriage:
This for our more acquaintance. Jewell.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How cloſe he kiſſes?
And how ſenſible the paſſings of his lips are?
I muſt do it, and I were to be hang'd now, and I will do it,
He may doe as much for me, that's all I ayme at,
And come what will on't, life or death, I'le do it,
For ten ſuch kiſſes more, and 'twere high treaſon.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I wou'd be private with her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So you ſhall,
'Tis not worth thankes elſe, you muſt diſpatch quick.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Suddenly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And I muſt leave you in my chamber ſir,
Where you muſt locke your ſelfe that none may ſee you,
'Tis cloſe to her, you cannot miſſe the entrance,
When ſhe comes downe to bed.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I underſtand ye, and once more thanke ye Lady.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thanke me but thus.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If I faile thee—
Come cloſe then. Ex.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: 'Tis late good Aunt, to bed, I am ene unready,
My! woman will not be long away.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: I wou'd have you a little merrier firſt,
Let me ſit by ye, and read or diſcourſe
Something that ye fancy, or take my inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: No, no I thanke you,
I ſhall ſleep without theſe, I wrong your age Aunt
To make ye waite thus, pray let me entreat ye,
To morrow I'le ſee ye, I know y'are ſleepy,
And reſt will be a welcome gueſt, you ſhall not, Enter Panura.
