Indeed you ſhall not ſtay; oh here's my woman,
Good night, good night, and good reſt Aunt attend you.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Sleep dwell upon your eyes, & faire dreams court ye.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Come, where have you been wench? make me unready;
I ſlept but ill laſt night.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You'l ſleep the better
I hope too night Madam.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: A little reſt contents me;
Thou loveſt thy bed Panura.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am not in love Lady,
Nor ſeldome dreame of devils, I ſleep ſoundly.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I'le ſweare thou doſt, thy husband wou'd not take it ſo well
If thou wert married wench.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Let him take Madam
The way to waken me, I am no dormouſe.
Husbands have larum bels, if they but
Ring once.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Thou art a merry wench.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I ſhall live the longer.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Prethee fetch my booke.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am glad of that.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I'le read a while before I ſleep.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: And if Ruy Dias meet you and be importunate,
He may come in.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I have a better fare for you,
Now leaſt in ſight play I. Exit.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Why ſhould I love him?
Why ſhould I doat upon a man deſerves not,
Nor has no will to worke it? who's there wench?
What are you? or whence come you?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Ye may know me,
I bring not ſuch amazement noble Lady.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Who let you in?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: My reſtles love that ſerves ye.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: This is an impudence I have not heard of,
A rudeneſſe that becomes a theefe or ruſſin;
Nor ſhall my brothers love protect this boldneſſe,
You buil'd ſo ſtrongly on, my roomes are ſanctuaries,
And with that reverence they that ſeeke my favours,
And humble feares, ſhall render their approches.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Mine are no leſſe.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I am Miſtris of my ſelfe ſir,
And will be ſo, I will not be thus viſited;
Theſe feares and dangers thruſt into my privacy,
Stand further off, I le cry out elſe.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Oh deare Lady!

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I ſee diſhonour in your eyes.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: There is none:
By all that beauty they are innocent;
Pray ye tremble not, you have no cauſe.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I'le dye firſt;
Before you have your will, be torne in peeces;
The little ſtrength I have left me to reſiſt you,
The gods will give me more, before I am forc'd
To that I hate, or ſuffer—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: You wrong my duty.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: So baſe a violation of my liberty?
I know you are bent unnobly; I'le take to me
The ſpirit of a man, borrow his boldneſſe,
And force my womans feares into a madneſſe,
And ere you arrive at what you aime at—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Lady,
If there be in you any womans pitty?
And if your feares have not proclam'd me monſtrous?
Looke on me and beleeve me; is this violence?
Is it to fall thus proſtrate to your beauty,
A ruffins boldneſſe? is humility a rudeneſſe?
The griefes and ſorrowes that grow here an impudence?
Theſe forcings, and theſe feares I bring along with me,
Theſe impudent abuſes offered ye;
And thus high has your brothers favour blowne me:
Alas deare Lady of my life, I came not
With any purpoſe rough, or deſperate,
With any thought that was not ſmooth and gentle
As your faire hand, with any doubt or danger,
Far be it from my heart to fright your quiet;
A heavy curſe light on it when I intend it.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Now I dare heare you.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If I had been miſchievous,
As then I muſt be mad; or were a monſter,
If any ſuch baſe thought had harbour'd here,
Or violence that became not man,
You have a thouſand bulwarkes to aſſure you,
The holy powers beare ſhields to defend chaſtity;
Your honour and your vertues are ſuch armours;
Your cleare thoughts ſuch defences; if you misdoubt ſtill,
And yet retaine a feare I am not honeſt,
Come with impure thoughts to this place;
Take this, and ſheath it heare; be your own ſafety;
Be wiſe, and rid your feares, and let me periſh;
How willing ſhall I ſleepe to ſatisfie you.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: No, I beleeve now, you ſpeake worthily;
What came you then for?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: To complaine, me beauty,
But modeſtly.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Of your feirce cruelty,
For though I dye, I will not blame the doer:
Humbly to tell your grace, ye had forgot me:
A little to have toucht at, not accuſed,
For that I dare not do, your ſcornes, pray pardon me
And be not angry, that I uſe the liberty
To urge that word, a little to have ſhew'd you
What I have been, and what done to deſerve ye,
If any thing that love commands may reach ye,
To have remembred ye, but I am unworthy,
And to that miſery fals all my fortunes,
To have told ye, and by my life ye may beleeve me,
That I am honeſt, and will only marry
You, or your memory; pray be not angry.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir, and let me tell you ſeriouſly,
Ye have taken now the right way to befriend ye,
And to beget a faire and cleare opinion,
Yet to try your obedience—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I ſtand ready Lady,
Without preſuming to aske any thing.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Or at this time to hope for further favour;
Or to remember ſervices, or ſmiles;
Dangers you have paſt through, and rewards due to 'em;
Loves or diſpaires, but leaving all to me:
Quit this place preſently.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I ſhall obey ye.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Who's this?
What art thou?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Thou art no more I'm ſure: oh 'tis Ruy Dias;
How high he lookes, and harſh?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Is there not doore enough,
You take ſuch elbow roome?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If I take it, I'le carry it.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Does this become you Princeſſe?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: The Captain's jealous,
Jealous of that he never durſt deſerve yet;
Go freely, go I'le give thee leave.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Your leave ſir?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Yes my leave ſir, I'le not be troubled neither,
Nor ſhall my heart ake, or my head be jealous,
Nor ſtrange ſuſpitious thoughts reigne in my memory;
Go on, and do thy worſt, I'le ſmile at thee;
I kiſſe your faire hand firſt, then farewell Captaine. Ex.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: What a pure ſoule inherits here? what innocence?
Sure I was blind when I firſt lov'd this fellow,
And long to live in that fogg ſtil: how he bluſters!

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Am I your property? or thoſe your flatteries,
The banquets that ye bid me to, the truſt
I build my goodly hopes on?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Be more temperate.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Are theſe the ſhewes of your reſpect and favour?
What did he here? what language had he with ye?
Did ye invite? could ye ſtay no longer?
Is he ſo gratious in your eye?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: You are too forward.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Why at theſe private houres?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: You are too ſaucy,
Too impudent to taske me with thoſe erours:
Do ye know what I am ſir, and my prerogative?
Though you be a thing I haue cal'd bith' name of friend,
I never taught you to diſpoſe my liberty;
How durſt you touch mine honour? blot my meanings?
And name an action, and of mine but noble?
Thou poore unworthy thing, how have I grac'd thee?
How have I nouriſht thee, and raiſed thee hourely?
Are theſe the gratitudes you bring Ruy Dias?
The thankes? the ſervices? I am fairely paid;
Was't not enough I ſaw thou wert a Coward,
And ſhaddowed thee? no noble ſparkle in thee?
Dayly provok'd thee, and ſtill found thee coward?
Rais'd noble cauſes for thee, ſtrangers ſtarted at;
Yet ſtill, ſtill, ſtill a Coward, ever Coward;
And with thoſe taints, doſt thou upbraid my vertues?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I was too blame
Lady.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: So blindly bold to touch at my behaviour?
Durſt thou but looke amiſſe at my allowance?
If thou hadſt been a brave fellow, thou hadſt had ſome licence,
Some liberty I might have then allowed thee
For thy good face, ſome ſcope to have argued with me;
But being nothing but a ſound, a ſhape,
The meere ſigne of a Souldier — of a Lover,
The dregs and draffy part, diſgrace and jealouſie,
I ſcorne thee, and contemne thee.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Deareſt Lady,
If I have been too free—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Thou haſt been too fooliſh,
And goe on ſtill, I'le ſtudy to forget thee,
I would I could, and yet I pitty thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I am not worth it, if I were, that's miſery,
The next doore is but death, I muſt aime at it. Exit.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter King, and Governor like a Moore Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: SOe far and truly you have diſcovered to me
The former currents of my life and fortune,
That I am bound to acknowledge ye moſt holy,
And certainly to credit your predictions
Of what are yet to come.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am no lyer,
'Tis ſtrange I ſhould, and live ſo neare a neighbour;
But theſe are not my ends.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Pray ye ſit good father,
Certaine a reverend man, and moſt religious.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I, that beliefe's well now, and let me worke then,
I'le make ye curſe religion ere I leave ye;
I have liv'd a long time ſon, a mewd up man,
Sequeſter'd by the ſpeciall hand of heaven
From the worlds vanities, bid farewell to follies,
And ſhooke hands with all heats of youth and pleaſures,
As in a dreame theſe twenty yeares I have ſlumber'd,
Many a cold moone have I in meditation,
And ſearching out the hidden wils of heaven,
Laine ſhaking under, many a burning Sun
Has fear'd my body, and boyl'd up my bloud,
Feebl'd my knees, and ſtampt a Meagerneſſe
Upon my figure, all to find out knowledge,
Which I have now attained too, thankes to heaven,
All for my countries good too, and many a viſion,
Many a miſticke viſion have I ſeen ſon,
And many a ſight from heaven which has been terrible,
Wherein the goods and evils of theſe Iſlands
Were lively ſhadowed; many a charge I have had too,
Still as the time grew ripe to reveale theſe,
To travell and diſcover, now I am come ſon,
The houre is now appointed,
My tongue is touch'd, and now I ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Do holy man, I'le heare ye.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Beware theſe Portugals, I ſay beware 'em,
Theſe ſmooth fac'd ſtrangers, have an eye upon 'em.
The cauſe is now the God's, heare, and beleeve King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I do heare, but before I give raſh credit,
Or hang too light on beliefe, which is a ſin father;
Know I have found 'em gentle, faithfull, valiant,
And am in my particular, bound to 'em,
I meane to ſome for my moſt ſtrange deliverance.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: O Son, the future aimes of men, obſerve me,
Above their preſent actions, and their glory,
Are to be look'd at: the ſtars ſhew many turnings,
If you could ſee, marke but with my eyes pupill;
Theſe men came hether as my viſion tels me,
Poore, weatherbeaten, almoſt loſt, ſtarv'd, feebled,
Their veſſels like themſelves, moſt miſerable;
Made a long ſute for traffique, and for comfort,
To vent their childrens toyes, cure their diſeaſes:
They had their ſute, they landed, and too th'rate
Grew rich and powerfull, ſuckt the fat, and freedome
Of this moſt bleſſed Iſle, taught her to tremble,
Witneſſe the Caſtle here, the Cittadell,
They have clapt upon the necke of your Tidore,
This happy town, till that ſhe knew theſe ſtrangers,
To check her when ſhee's jolly.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: They have ſo indeed father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Take heed, take heed, I find your faire delivery,
Though you be pleas'd to glorifie that fortune,
And thinke theſe ſtrangers Gods, take heed I ſay,
I find it but a hanſome preparation,
A faire fac'd Prologue to a further miſchiefe:
Marke but the end good King, the pin he ſhootes at
That was the man deliver'd ye; the mirrour,
Your Siſter is his due; what's ſhe, your heire ſir?
And what's he a kin then to the Kingdome?
But heires are not ambitious, who then ſuffers?
What reverence ſhall the Gods have? and what juſtice
The miſerable people? what ſhall they doe?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: He points at truth directly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Thinke of theſe ſon:
The perſon, nor the manner I miſlike not
Of your preſerver, nor the whole man together,
Were he but ſeaſon'd in the faith we are,
Ne, our devotions learn'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You ſay right father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To change our worſhips now, and our Religion?
To be traytor to our God?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have well adviſed me,
And I will ſeriouſly conſider father,
In the meane time you ſhall have your faire acceſſe
Unto my ſiſter, adviſe her to your purpoſe,
And let me ſtill know how the Gods determine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I will, but my maine end is to adviſe
The deſtruction of you all, a generall ruine,
And then I am reveng'd, let the Gods whiſtle. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Indeed, I am right glad ye were not greedie,
And ſuddaine in performing what I wild you,
Upon the perſon of Armuſia,
I was affraid, for I well knew your valour,
And love to me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: 'Twas not a faire thing unckle,
It ſhewd not hanſome, carried no man in it.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe 'twas ill, and I abhor it,
Only this good has riſen from this evill;
I have tried your honeſtie, and find proofe,
A conſtancie that will not be corrupted,
And I much honour it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This Bell ſounds better.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: My anger now, and that diſgrace I have ſuffer'd,
Shall be more manly vented, and wip'd off,
And my ſicke honour cur'd the right and ſtraight way;
My Swords in my hand now nephew, my cauſe upon it,
And man to man, one vallour to another,
My hope to his.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Why? this like Ruy Dias?
This carries ſomething of ſome ſubſtance in it;
Some mettle and ſome man, this ſounds a gentleman;
And now methinkes ye utter what becomes ye;
To kill men ſcurvily, 'tis ſuch a dog tricke,
Such a ratcatchers occupation —

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: It is no better,
But Pyniero now—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now I do bravely.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: The difference of our ſtates ſlung by forgotten,
The full opinion I have won in ſervice,
And ſuch reſpects that may not ſhew us equall,
Laid hanſomely aſide, only our fortunes,
And ſingle manhoods—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: In a ſervice ſir,
Of this moſt noble nature, all I am,
If I had ten lives more, thoſe and my fortunes
Are ready for ye, I had thought ye had forſworn fighting,
Or baniſh'd thoſe brave thoughts were wont to waite upon you Shews a Challenge
I am glad to ſee 'em cal'd home agen.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: They are nephew,
And thou ſhall ſee what fire they carry in them,
Here, you gueſſe what this meanes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Yes, very well ſir,
A portion of Scripture that puzzels many an interpreter.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: As ſoone as you can find him—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: That will not be long unckle,
And o' my conſcience heele be ready as quickly.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I make no doubt good Nephew, carry it ſo
If you can poſſible that we may ſight.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Nay, you ſhall fight aſſure your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Pray ye heare me
In ſome ſuch place where it may be poſſible
The Princeſſe may behold us.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I conceive ye,
Upon the ſand behind the Caſtle ſir,
A place remote enough, and there be windows
Out of her lodgings too, or I am miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Y'are i'th' right, if ye can worke that hanſomly —

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Let me alone, and pray be you prepar'd
Some three houres hence.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I will not faile.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Get you home,
And if you have any things to diſpoſe of,
Or a few light prayers
That may befriend you, run 'em over quickely,
I warrant, I'le bring him on.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Farewell Nephew,
And when we meet againe —

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I, I, fight handſomely;
Take a good draught or two of wine to ſettle ye,
'Tis an excellent armour for an ill conſcience Unckle;
I am glad to ſee, this mans converſion,
I was affraid faire honour had been bedrid,
Or beaten out o'th' Iſland, ſouldiers and good ones,
Intended ſuch baſe courſes? he will fight now;
And I beleeve too bravely; I have ſeene him
Curry a fellowes carkaſſe hanſomely:
And in the head of a troope ſtand as if he had been rooted there,
Dealing large doles of death; what a raſcall was I
I did not ſee his will drawn?
What does ſhe here? Enter Quiſara.
If there be any miſchief toward, a woman makes one ſtil;
Now what new buſineſſe is for me?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I was ſending for ye,
But ſince we have met ſo faire,
You have ſav'd that labour; I muſt entreat you ſir—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Any thing Madam,
Your wils are my commands.

sp.speaker: Quſar.
sp.l: Y'are nobly courteous;
Upon my better thoughts Signeor Pyniero,
And my more peaceable conſiderations.
Which now I find the richer ornaments;
I wou'd deſire you to attempt no farther
Againſt the perſon of the noble ſtranger,
In truth I am aſhamd of my ſhare in't;
Nor be incited further by your unckle,
I ſee it will ſit ill upon your perſon;
I have conſidered, and it will ſhew ugly
Carried at beſt, a moſt unheard of cruelty;
Goood ſir deſiſt—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You ſpeake now like a woman,
And wondrous well this tenderneſſe becomes ye;
But this you muſt remember—your command
Was laid on with a kiſſe, and ſeriouſly
It muſt be taken off the ſame way Madam,
Or I ſtand bound ſtill.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: That ſhall not endanger ye,
Looke ye faire ſir, thus I take off that duty.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Byth' maſſe 'twas ſoft and ſweet,
Some blouds would bound now,
And run a tilt; do not you thinke bright beauty,
You have done me in this kiſſe a mighty favour,
And that I ſtand bound by vertue of this honour,
To do what ever you command me?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I thinke ſir,
From me theſe are unuſuall curteſies,
And ought to be reſpected ſo; there are ſome,
And men of no mean ranke, would hold themſelves
Not poorely bleſt to taſte of ſuch a bounty.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I know there are that wou'd do many unjuſt things
For ſuch a kiſſe, and yet I hold this modeſt;
All villanies body and ſoule diſpence with,
For ſuch a provocation, kill their kindred,
Demoliſh the faire credits of their Parents;
Thoſe kiſſes I am not acquainted with, moſt certaine Madam
The appurtenance of this kiſſe wou'd not provoke me
To do a miſchief, 'tis the devils owne dance,
To be kiſſ'd into cruelty.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I am glad you make that uſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I am gladder
That you made me beleeve you were cruell,
For by this hand I know I am ſo honeſt,
However I deceiv'd ye, 'twas high time too,
Some common ſlave might have been ſet upon it elſe,
That willingly I wou'd not kill a dog
That could but fetch and carry for a woman,
She muſt be a good woman made me kick him,
And that will be hard to find, to kill a man,
If you will give me leave to get another,
Or any ſhe that plaid the beſt game at it,
And fore a womans anger prefer her fancy.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I take it in you well.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I thanke ye Lady,
And I ſhall ſtudy to confirme it.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Do ſir,
For this time, and this preſent cauſe I 'low it,
Moſt holy ſir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Bleſſe ye my royall daughter,
And in you, bleſſe this Iſland heaven.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Good Aunt,
What thinke ye of this man?

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: Sure 'is a wiſe man,
And a religious, he tels us things have hapned
So many yeares agoe almoſt forgotten,
As readily, as if they were done this houre.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Does he not meet with your ſharpe tongue?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He tels me Madam,
Marriage, and mouldy cheeſe will make me tamer.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: A ſtubborne keeper, and worſe fare,
An open ſtable, and cold care,
Will tame a Jade, may be your ſhare.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Bir Lady, a ſharp prophet, when this proves good
I'le bequeath you a skin to make ye a hood.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Lady I would talke with you.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Do reverend ſir.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: And for you good, for that that muſt concerne ye,
And give eare wiſely to me.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I ſhall father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You are a Prinreſſe of that excellence,
Sweetneſſe, and grace, that Angell-like faire feature,
Nay, do not bluſh, I doe not flatter you,
Nor do I dote in telling this, I am amazed Lady,
And as I thinke the gods beſtow'd theſe on ye,
The gods that love ye.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I confeſſe their bounty.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Apply it then to their uſe, to their honour,
To them, and to their ſervice give this ſweetneſſe;
They have an inſtant great uſe of your goodneſſe;
You are a Saint eſteem'd here for your beauty,
And may a longing heart —

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I ſeeke no fealty,
Nor will I blemiſh that heaven has ſeal'd on me,
I know my worth, indeed the Portugals
I have at thoſe commands, and their laſt ſervices,
Nay, even their lives, ſo much I thinke my hanſomneſſe,
That what I ſhall enjoyne —

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Uſe it diſcreetly,
For I perceive ye underſtand me rightly,
For here the gods regard your helpe, and ſuddenly;
The Portugals like ſharpe thornes (marke me Lady)
Sticke in our ſides, like razors, wound religion,
Draw deep, they wound, till the life bloud followes,
Our gods they ſpurne at, and their worſhips ſcorne,
A mighty hand they beare upon our government,
Theſe are the men your miracle muſt worke on,
Your heavenly forme, either to roote them out,
Which as you may endeavour will be eaſie,
Remember whoſe great cauſe you have to execute,
To nip their memory, that may not ſpring more,
Or fairely bring 'em home to our devotions,
Which will be bleſſed, and for which, you ſainted,
But cannot be, and they go; let me buzzle.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Go up with me,
Where wee'l converſe more privately;
I'le ſhew ye ſhortly how I hold their temper;
And in what chaine their ſoules.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Keep faſt that hold ſtill,
And either bring that chaine, and thoſe bound in it,
And linke it to our gods, and their faire worſhips,
Or daughter pinch their hearts a peeces with it,
I'le waite upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Come reverend father.
Waite you below. Ex. Quiſar. and Gov.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: If this prophet were a young thing,
I ſhould ſuſpect him now, he cleaves ſo cloſe to her;
Theſe holy coats are long, and hide in iniquities.

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: Away, away foole, a poore wretch,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Theſe poore ones
Warme but their ſtomakes once —

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.p: Come in, thou art fooliſh. Ex. Quiſan. and Pan.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am ſorry ſir my fortune is ſo ſtubborne,
To court my ſword againſt my countriman,
I love my nation well, and where I find
A Portugall of noble name and vertue,
I am his humble ſervant. Signeor Pyniero,
Your perſon, nor your unckles am I angry with,
You are both faire Gentlemen in my opinion,
And I proteſt, I had rather uſe my ſword
In your defences, then againſt your ſafeties;
'Tis me thinkes, a ſtrange dearth of enemies,
When we ſeeke foes among our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You are injured,
And you muſt make the beſt on't now, and readieſt—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: You ſee I am ready in the place; and arm'd
To his deſire that cald me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye ſpeake honeſtly,
And I could wiſh ye had met on tearmes more friendly,
But it cannot now be ſo. Enter Ruy Dias.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Turne ſir, and ſee.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I have kept my word with ye unckle,
The Gentleman is ready. Enter Governour, and Quiſara above.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Ye are welcome.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Bid thoſe fooles welcome that affect your curteſie,
I come not to uſe complement, ye have wrongd' me,
And ye ſhall feele proud man ere I part from ye,
The effects of that, if fortune do not foole me;
Thy life is mine, and no hope ſhall redeeme thee.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: That's a proud word,
More then your faith can juſtifie.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Sure they will fight.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: She's there, I am happy.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Let 'em alone, let 'em kill one another,
Theſe are the maine poſtes, if they fall, the buildings
Will tumple quickely.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: How temperate Armuſia?
No more, be quiet yet.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am not bloudy,
Nor do not feele ſuch mortall malice in me,
But ſince we cannot both enjoy the Princeſſe,
I am reſolv'd to fight.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Fight home Armuſia,
For if thou faint'ſt, or fall'ſt—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Do ye make all vantages?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Alwaies; unto thy life I will not ſpare thee,
Nor looke not for thy mercy.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am arm'd then.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Stand ſtill I charge ye nephew, as ye honour me.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: And good Emanuel—not—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ye ſpeake fitly,
For we had not ſtood idle elſe.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I am ſorry for't.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: But ſince you will have it ſo—

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: Come ſir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I waight ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I marry this looks hanſomely,
This is warme worke.

sp.speaker: Gov
sp.l: Both fall an't be thy will. Ruy fals.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: My Unckle dead?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Stand ſtill, or my ſwords in—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now brave Ruy Dias,
Now Where's your confidence, your prayers? quickly
Your owne ſpite has condemn'd ye.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Hold Armuſia.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Moſt happy Lady.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Hold and let him riſe,
Spare him for me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A long life may he enjoy Lady.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What ha' you done? 'tis better they had all periſht.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Peace father, I worke for the beſt; Armuſia,
Be in the garden an houre hence. Ex. Qu. and Gov.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I ſhall Madam.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now as I live a Gentleman at all inches,
So brave a mingled temper ſaw I never.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why are ye ſad ſir? how would this have griev'd you,
If ye had falne under a profeſt enemie?
Under one had taken vantage of your ſhame too?
Pray ye be at peace, I am ſo far from wronging ye,
Or glorying in the pride of ſuch a victorie,
That I deſire to ſerve ye, pray look cheerfully

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Doe you heare this ſir? this love ſir? do you ſee this Gentleman
How he courts ye? why doe you hold your head downe?
Tis no high treaſon I take it, to be equal'd,
To have a ſlip i'th' field, no ſinne that's mortall;
Come, come, thanke fortune and your friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It may be
You thinke my tongue may prove your enemie;
And though reſtrain'd ſometimes, out of a braverie
May take a licenſe to diſable ye:
Beleeve me ſir, ſo much I hate that libertie,
That in a ſtrangers tongue 't will prove an injurie,
And I ſhall right you in't.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Can you have more Unckle?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Sir you have beate me both wayes, yet ſo nobly,
That I ſhall ever love the hand that did it:
Fortune may make me worthie of ſome title
That may be neere your friend.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir I muſt leave ye,
But with ſo hearty love, and pray be confident, Ex. Arm. & Em.
I carry nothing from this place ſhall wrong ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come, come, you are right agen, ſir love your honor,
And love your friend, take heed of bloudy purpoſes,
And unjuſt ends, good heaven is angry with 'm;
Make your faire vertues, and your fame your miſtres,
And let theſe trinkets goe.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: You teach well nephew,
Now to be honorable even with this Gentleman,
Shall be my buſineſſe, and my ends his.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Sir, ſir, you muſt doe ſomething ſuddenly,
To ſtop his pride ſo great and high, he is ſhot up,
Upon his perſon too, your ſtate is ſunke elſe:
You muſt not ſtand now upon termes of gratitude,
And let a ſimple tenderneſſe beſot ye:
I'le bring ye ſuddenly where you ſhall ſee him,
Attempting your brave ſiſter privately;
Marke but his high behaviour then.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I will Father.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: And with ſcorne, I feare contempt too.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I will not name a luſt;
It may be that alſo;
A little force muſt be applyed upon him,
Now, now applyed, a little force to humble him.
Theſe ſweet intreaties doe but make him wanton.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Take heed ye wrong him not.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Take heed to your ſafety,
I but fore warne ye King; if you miſtruſt me,
Or thinke I come unſent—

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: No I'le goe with you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Madam, you ſee there's nothing I can reach at,
Either in my obedience, or my ſervice,
That May deſerve your love, or win a liking,
But a poore thought, but I purſue it ſeriouſly,
Take pleaſure in your wils, even in your anger,
Which other men would grudge at, and grow ſtormy;
I ſtudy new humility to pleaſe ye,
And take a kind of joy in my afflictions,
Becauſe they come from ye, I love my ſorrowes:
Pray Madam but conſider—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Yes, I do ſir,
And to that honeſt end I drew ye hether;
I know ye have deſerv'd as much as man can,
And know it is a juſtice to requite you:
I know ye love.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: If ever love was mortall,
And dwelt in man, and for that love command me,
So ſtrong I find it, and ſo true, here Lady,
Something of ſuch a greatneſſe to allow me,
Thoſe things I have done already, may ſeem foyles too:
'Tis equity that man aſpires to heaven,
Should win it by his worth, and not ſleepe to it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now ſtand cloſe King and heare, and as you find him,
Beleeve me right, or let religion ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I dare beleeve your worth without additions;
But ſince you are ſo liberall of your love ſir,
And wou'd be farther tried, I do intend it,
Becauſe you ſhall not, or you wou'd not win me
At ſuch an eaſie rate.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am prepared ſtill,
And if I ſhrinke—

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I know ye are no coward,
This is the utmoſt triall of your conſtancy,
And if you ſtand faſt now, I am yours, your wife ſir;
You hold there's nothing deare that may atchieve me,
Doubted or dangerous.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: There's nothing, nothing:
Let me but know, that I may ſtraight flie to it.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I'le tell you then, change your religion,
And be of one beleefe with me.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Marke,
Worſhip our Gods, renounce that faith you are bred in;
'Tis eaſily done, I'le teach ye ſuddenly;
And humbly on your knees—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Ha! I'le be hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Offer as we do.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: To the Devill Lady?
Offer to him I hate? I know the devill,
To dogs and cats? you make offer to them;
To every bird that flies, and every worme.
How terribly I ſhake? Is this the venture?
The tryall that you talkt off? where have I bin?
And how forgot my ſelfe? how loſt my memorie?
When did I pray or looke up ſtedfaſtly?
Had any goodnes in my heart to guide me?
That I ſhould give this vantage to mine enemie;
The enemie to my peace, forſake my faith.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Come, come, I know ye love me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love ye this way?
This moſt deſtroying way? ſure you but jeſt Lady.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: My love and life are one way.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love alone then, and mine another way,
I'le love diſeaſes firſt,
Doate on a villaine that would cut my throat,
Wooe all afflictions of all ſorts, kiſſe crueltie;
Have mercy heaven, how have I been wandring?
Wandring the way of luſt, and left my maker?
How have I ſlept like Corke upon a water,
And had no feeling of the ſtorme that toſt me?
Trod the blinde paths of death? forſooke aſſurance,
Eternitie of bleſſedneſſe for a woman?
For a young hanſome face hazard my being?

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: Are not our powers eternall ſo their comforts?
As great and full of hopes as yours?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: They are puppits.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now marke him ſir, and but obſerve him nearly,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Their comforts like themſelves, cold ſenſeles outſides;
You make 'em ſicke, as we are, peeviſh, mad,
Subject to age; and how can they cure us,
That are not able to reſine themſelves?

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: The Sun & Moon we worſhip, thoſe are heavenly,
And their bright influences we beleeve.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Away foole,
I adore the Maker of that Sun and Moone,
That gives thoſe bodies light and influence,
That pointed out their paths, and taught their motions;
They are not ſo great as we, they are our ſervants,
Plac'd there to teach us time, to give us knowledge
Of when and how the ſwellings of the maine aire,
And their returnes agen; they are but our ſtewards
To make the earth fat with their influence,
That ſhe may bring forth her increaſe and feed us.
Shall I fall from this faith to pleaſe a woman?
For her embraces bring my ſoule to ruine?
I lookd you ſhould have ſaid, make me a Chriſtian,
Worke that great cure, for 't is a great one woman;
That labour truly doe performe, that venture
The crowne of all great triall, and the faireſt:
I lookd ye ſhould have wept and kneel'd to beg it,
Waſht off your miſt of ignorance, with waters
Pure and repentant, from thoſe eyes; I lookt
You ſhould have brought me your chief god ye worſhip,
He that you offer humane bloud and life to,
And made a ſacrifice of him to memorie,
Beat downe his Altars, ruin'd his falſe Temples.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now you may ſee.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: Take heed, you goe too far ſir,
And yet I love to heare him; I muſt have ye,
And to that end I let you ſtorme a little;
I know there muſt be ſome ſtrife in your boſome
To coole and quiet ye, ere you can come backe:
I know old friends cannot part ſuddenly,
There wil be ſome let ſtill, yet I muſt have ye,
Have ye of my faith too, and ſo injoy ye.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Now I contemne ye, and I hate my ſelfe
For looking on that face laſciviouſly,
And it lookes ugly now methinkes.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: How Portugall?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It lookes like death it ſelfe, to which 'twou'd lead me;
Your eyes reſemble pale diſpaire, they fright me,
And in their rounds a thouſand horrid ruines,
Methinkes I ſee; and in your tongue heare fearefully
The hideous murmurs of weake ſoules have ſuffer'd;
Get from me, I deſpiſe ye, and know woman,
That for all this trap you have laid to catch my life in,
To catch my immortall life, I hate and curſe ye,
Contemne your deities, ſpurne at their powers,
And where I meet your maumet Gods, I'le ſwing 'em
Thus o're my head, and kick 'em into puddles,
Nay I will out of vengeance ſearch your Temples,
And with thoſe hearts that ſerve my God, demoliſh
Your ſhambles of wild worſhips.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now, now you heare ſir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I will have my faith ſince you are ſo crafty,
The glorious croſſe, although I love your brother;
Let him frowne too, I will have my devotion,
And let your whole State ſtorme.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Enter and take him;
I am ſorry friend that I am forc'd to do this.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Be ſure you bind him faſt.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: But uſe him nobly.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Had it to me been done, I had forgiven it,
And ſtill preſerv'd you faire, but to our Gods ſir —

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Methinkes I hate 'em now,

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: To our Religion,
To theſe to be thus ſtubborne, thus rebellious
To threaten them.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Uſe all your violence,
I aske no mercy, nor repent my words;
I ſpit at your beſt powers; I ſerve one,
Will give me ſtrength to ſcourge your gods.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: To grind 'em into baſe duſt, and diſperſe 'em,
That never more their bloudy memories—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Clap him cloſe up.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Good friend be cooler.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Never;
Your painted ſiſter I deſpiſe too.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Softly.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: And all her devilliſh arts laugh and ſcorne at,
Mocke her blind purpoſes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You muſt be temperate;
Offer him no violence I command you ſtrictly.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Now thou art up I ſhall have time to ſpeake too.

sp.speaker: Quiſ.
sp.l: Oh how I love this man, how truly honour him.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Chriſtophero, and Pedro (at one doore) Emanuel. and Soza, (at another.)

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: DDo you know the newes Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Wou'd we knew as well ſir
How to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Is this the love they beare us,
For our late benefit? taken ſo maliciouſly,
And clapt up cloſe? is that the thankes they render?

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: It muſt not be put up thus, ſmother'd ſleightly,
'Tis ſuch a baſe unnaturall wrong.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I know,
They may thinke to doe wonders, aime at all,
And to blow us with a vengeance out o'th' Iſlands:
But if we be our ſelves honeſt and reſolute,
And continue but Maſters of our ancient courages,
Sticke cloſe and give no vantage to their villanies—

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Nay if we faint or fall apeeces now,
We are fooles and worthy to be markt for miſerie;
Begin to ſtrike at him they are all bound to?
To cancell his deſerts? what muſt we looke for
If they can carry this?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I'le carry coales then;
I have but one life, and one fortune Gentlemen,
But I'le ſo husband it to vexe theſe raſcalls,
Theſe barbarous ſlaves.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Shall we goe charge 'em preſently?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: No that will be too weake, and too foole-hardy,
We muſt have grounds that promiſe ſafety friends,
And ſure offence, we looſe our angers elſe,
And worſe then that, venture our lives too lightly.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Did you ſee mine Uncle? plague 'a theſe Barbarians,
How the rogues ſticke in my teeth, I know ye are angry,
So I am too, monſtrous angry Gentlemen,
I am angry that I choke agen.
You heare Armuſias up, honeſt Arm:
Clapt up in priſon friends, the brave Arm:
Here are fine boyes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: We hope he ſhall not ſtay there.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Stay? no he muſt not ſtay, no talke of ſtaying,
Theſe are no times to ſtay; are not theſe Raſcals?
Speake, I beſeech ye ſpeake, are they not Rogues?
Thinke ſome abominable names — are they not Devils?
But the devil's a great deale too good for 'em — fuſty vil|laines.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: They are a kind of hounds.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Hounds were their fathers,
Old blear-eyed bob-tail'd hounds — Lord where's my Unckle?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: But what ſhall be done ſir?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Done?

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Yes to relieve him;
If it be not ſudden they may take his life too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: They dare as ſoone take fire and ſwallow it,
Take ſtakes and thruſt into their tailes for gliſters:
His life, why 'tis a thing worth all the Iſlands,
And they know will be rated at that value;
His very impriſonment will make the Town ſtinch,
And ſhake and ſtinke, I have phiſick in my hand for 'em
Shall give the goblins ſuch a purge —

sp.speaker: Ped
sp.l: Your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I heare ſtrange newes, and have bin ſeeking ye;
They ſay Armuſia's priſoner.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt certaine.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Upon what cauſe?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He has deſerv'd too much ſir;
The old heathen policie has light upon him,
And paid him home.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: A moſt unnoble dealing.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You are the next if you can carry it tamely,
He has deſerved of all.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe it,
Of me ſo nobly too.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I am glad to heare it,
You have a time now to make good your confeſſion,
Your faith will ſhew but cold elſe, and for faſhion,
Now to redeeme all, now to thanke his courteſie,
Now to make thoſe beleeve that held you backward,
And an ill inſtrument, you are a Gentleman,
An honeſt man, and you dare love your Nation,
Dare ſticke to vertue though ſhe be oppreſt,
And for her owne faire ſake ſtep to her Reſcue:
If you live ages ſir, and loſe this houre,
Not now redeeme, and vindicate your honour,
Your life will be a murmure, and no man in't.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: I thanke ye nephew, come along with me Gentle|men,
Wee'l make 'em dancing ſport immediately:
We are Maſters of the Fort yet, we ſhall ſee
What that can doe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Let it but ſpit fire finely,
And play their turrets, and their painted Palaces,
A frisking round or two, that they may trip it,
And caper in the aire.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Come, wee'l doe ſomething
Shall make 'em looke about, wee'l ſend 'em plumbes
If they be not too hard for their teeth.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And fine Potatoes
Roaſted in gunpowder, ſuch a banquet ſir
Will prepare their unmannerly ſtomacks.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: They ſhall ſee
There is no ſafe retreat in villanie;
Come be high hearted all.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: We are all on fire ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I am ungratefull, and a wretch, perſwade me not,
Forgetfull of the mercy he ſhow'd me,
The timely noble pitty — why ſhould I
See him faſt bound and fetter'd, whoſe true curteſie,
Whoſe manhood, and whoſe mighty hand ſet me free?
Why ſhould it come from me? why I command this?
Shall not all tongues and truths call me unthankfull?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Had the offence bin thrown on you, 'tis certaine
It had been in your power, and your diſcretion
To have turn'd it into mercy, and forgiven it,
And then it had ſhow'd a vertuous point of gratitude,
Timely and nobly taken; but ſince the cauſe
Concernes the honour of our gods, and their title,
And ſo tranſcends your power, and your compaſſion,
A little your owne ſafety if you ſaw it too,
If your too fond indulgence did not dazle you,
It cannot now admit a private pitty;
'Tis in their wils, their mercies, or revenges,
And theſe revolts in you ſhew meere rebellious.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: They are milde and pittifull.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To thoſe repent.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Their nature's ſoft and tender.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: To true hearts
That feele compunction for their treſpaſſes:
This man defies 'em ſtill, threatens deſtruction
And demolition of their armes and worſhip,
Spits at their powers; take heed ye be not found ſir,
And markt a favourer of their diſhonour;
They uſe no common juſtice.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: What ſhall I doe
To deſerve of this man —

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: If ye more bemoane him,
Or mitigate your power to preſerve him,
I'le curſe ye from the gods, call up their vengeance,
sp.stage: Enter Quiſara with her hands bound, Quiſana, Panura.
sp.l: And fling it on your Land and you, I have charge for't;
I hope to wracke you all.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What ailes my ſiſter?
Why is ſhe bound? why looks ſhe ſo diſtractedly?
Who does doe this?

sp.speaker: Quiſan.
sp.l: We did it, pardon ſir,
And for her preſervation — She is growne wilde,
And raving on the ſtrangers love and honour,
Sometimes crying out, help, help, they will torture him,
They will take his life, they will murder him, preſently,
If we had not prevented, violently
Have laid hands on her owne life.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Theſe are tokens
The gods diſpleaſure is gone out, be quicke,
And ere it fall doe ſomething to appeaſe 'em,
You know the ſacrifice — I am glad it works thus.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: How low and baſe thou lookſt now that wert noble?
No figure of a King methinks ſhowes on you,
No face of Majeſtie, foule ſwarth ingratitude
Has taken off thy ſweetneſſe, baſe forgetfulneſſe
Of mighty benefits, has turned thee Devill:
Thou haſt perſecuted goodnes, innocence,
And laid a hard and violent hand on vertue,
On that faire vertue that ſhould teach and guide us;
Thou haſt wrong'd thine owne preſerver, whoſe leaſt merit
Pois'd with thy maine eſtate, thou canſt not ſatisfie,
Nay put thy life in too, 'twill be too light ſtill:
What haſt thou done?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Goe for him preſently.
And once more wee'l try it we can win him fairely:
If not, let nothing ſhe ſayes hinder ye, or ſtir ye;
She ſpeaks diſtractedly — Do that the gods command ye:
Doe you know what ye ſay Lady?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: I could curſe thee too,
Religion and ſeveritie has ſteel'd thee,
Has turnd thy heart to ſtone; thou haſt made the gods hard too,
Againſt their ſweet and patient natures, cruell:
None of ye feele what braverie ye tread on?
What innocence? what beauty?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Pray be patient.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: What honorable things ye caſt behind ye?
What monuments of man?

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Once more Armuſia,
Becauſe I love ye tenderly and dearly,
And would be glad to win ye mine, I wiſh ye,
Even from my heart I wiſh and wooe ye—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What ſir,
Take heed how ye perſwade me falſely, then ye hate me;
Take heed how ye intrap me.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I adviſe ye,
And tenderly and truly I adviſe ye,
Both for your ſoules health and your ſafetie.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stay,
And name my ſoule no more, ſhe is too precious,
Too glorious for your flatteries, too ſecure too.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Conſider the reward ſir, and the honor
That is prepared, the glory you ſhall grow to.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: They are not to be conſider'd in theſe caſes,
Not to be nam'd when ſoules are queſtioned;
They are vaine and flying vapors — touch my life,
'Tis ready for ye, put it to what teſt
It ſhall pleaſe ye, I am patient; but for the reſt
You may remove rocks with your little fingers,
Or blow a mountaine out o'th' way, with bellowes,
As ſoon as ſtir my faith; uſe no more arguments.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: We muſt uſe tortures then.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Your worſt and paineful'ſt
I am joyfull to accept.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: You muſt the ſharpeſt,
For ſuch has been your hate againſt our deities
Delivered openly, your threats and ſcornings,
And either your repentance muſt be mighty,
Which is your free converſion to our cuſtomes,
Or equall puniſhment, which is your life ſir.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I am glad I have it for ye, take it Prieſt,
And all the miſeries that ſhall attend it:
Let the Gods glut themſelves with Chriſtian bloud,
It will be ask'd againe, and ſo far followed,
So far reveng'd, and with ſuch holy juſtice,
Your Gods of gold ſhall melt and ſinke before it;
Your Altars, and your Temples ſhake to nothing;
And you falſe worſhippers, blind fooles of ceremony,
Shall ſeeke for holes to hide your heads, and feares in,
For ſeas to ſwallow you from this deſtruction,
Darkeneſſe to dwell about ye, and conceale ye,
Your mothers wombes agen—

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Make the fires ready,
And bring the ſeverall tortures out.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Stand faſt ſir,
And feare 'em not, you that have ſtept ſo nobly
Into this pious triall ſtart not now,
Keepe on your way, a virgin will aſſiſt ye,
A virgin won by your faire conſtancy,
And glorying that ſhe is won ſo, will dye by ye;
I have touch'd ye every way, tried ye moſt honeſt,
Perfect, and good, chaſte, bluſhing chaſte, and temperate,
Valiant, without vaineglory, modeſt, ſtayed,
No rage, or light affection ruling in you:
Indeed, the perfect ſchoole of worth I find ye,
The temple of true honour.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Whether will ſhe?
What do you infer by this faire argument Lady?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Your faith, and your religion muſt be like ye,
They that can ſhew you theſe, muſt be pure mirrours,
When the ſtreames flow cleare and faire, what are fountaines?
I do embrace your faith ſir, and your fortune;
Go one, I will aſſiſt ye, I feele a ſparkle here,
A lively ſparke that kindles my affection,
And tels me it will riſe to flames of glory:
Let 'em put on their angers, ſuffer nobly,
Shew me the way, and when I faint inſtruct me;
And if I follow not—

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: O bleſſed Lady,
Since thou art won, let me begin my triumph,
Come clap your terrors on.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: All your fell tortures.
For there is nothing he ſhall ſuffer brother,
I ſweare by new faith which is moſt ſacred,
And I will keepe it ſo, but I will follow in,
And follow to a ſcruple of affliction,
In ſpight of all your Gods without prevention.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Death ſhe amazes me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What ſhall be done now?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They muſt dye both,
And ſuddenly, they will corrupt all elſe;
This woman makes me weary of my miſchiefe,
She ſhakes me, and ſhe ſtaggers me, go in ſir.
I'le ſee the execution.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Not ſo ſuddaine:
If they goe all my friends and ſiſters periſh.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Wou'd I were ſafe at home agen.

sp.speaker: Meſ
sp.l: Arme, arme ſir,
Seek for defence, the Caſtle playes and thunders,
The Towne Rocks, and the houſes flye ith' aire,
The people dye for feare—Captaine Ruy Dias,
Has made an Oath he will not leave a ſtone here;
No not the memory, here has ſtood a City,
Unleſſe Armuſia be deliver'd fairely.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I have my feares: what can our gods do now for us?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Be patient, But keep him ſtill: he is a cure ſir
Againſt both rage and Cannon: goe and fortifie,
Call in the Princeſſe, make the Pallace ſure,
And let 'em know you are a King: look nobly;
And take your courage to ye; keep cloſe the priſoner,
And under command, we are betray'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How ioyfully I goe?

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Take my heart with thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I hold a Wolfe by the eare now:
Fortune free me. Exeunt.
Heaven bleſſe us,
What a thundring's here? what fire-ſpitting?
We cannot drinke, but our Cans are mald amongſt us.
I wou'd they would mall our skores too:
Shame o'their Guns, I thought they had been bird-pots,
Or great Candlecaſes, how deviliſhly they bounce,
And how the Bullets borrow a piece of a houſe here,
There another, and mend thoſe up agen
With another pariſh; here flyes a poudring-tub,
The meat ready roaſted & there a barrel piſſing vinegar,
And they two over-taking the top of a high Steeple,
Newly ſlic'd off for a ſallet.
A vengeance fire 'em.
Nay they fire faſt enough;
You need not help 'em.
Are theſe the Portugall Bulls—
How loud they bellow?
Their horns are plaguie ſtrong, they puſh down Pallaces
They toſſe our little habitations like whelps,
Like grindle-tailes, with their heeles upward;
All the windowes ith' town dance a new trench-more,
'Tis like to prove a bleſſed age for Glaſiers,
I met a hand, and a Letter in't in great haſte,
And by and by a ſingle leg running after it,
As if the Arme had forgot part of his arrant,
Heads ſhe like foot-balls every where.
What ſhall we doe?
I care not, my ſhop's cancell'd,
And all the Pots and earthen pans in't vaniſh't:
There was a ſingle Bullet and they together by the eares;
You would have thought Tom Tumbler had been there,
And all his troop of devills.
Let's to the King,
And get this gentleman deliver'd handſomely;
By this hand there's no walking above ground elſe.
By this leg—Let me ſweare nimbly by it,
For I know not how long I ſhall owe it,
If I were out oth' Towne once, if I came in agen to
Fetch my breakfaſt, I will give 'em leave to cram me
With a Portugall pudding: Come, let's doe any thing
To appeaſe this thunder, Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pyn.
sp.l: Art ſure it was that blinde prieſt?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes moſt certaine,
He has provok't all this; the King is mercifull,
And wondrous loving; but he fires him on ſtill,
And when he cooles enrages him, I know it,
Threatens new vengeance, and the gods fierce juſtice
When he but looks with faire eyes on Armuſia,
Will lend him no time to relent; my royall Miſtris,
She has entertain'd a Chriſtian hope.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Speake truely.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nay 'tis moſt true, but Lord, how he lies at her,
And threatens her, and flatters her, and dams her,
And I feare, if not ſpeedily prevented,
If ſhe continue ſtout, both ſhall be executed.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ile kiſſe thee for this newes: nay more Panura,
If thou wilt give me leave, Ile get thee with Chriſtian,
The beſt way to convert thee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Make me believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I will y'faith. But which way cam'ſt thou hither?
The Pallace is cloſe guarded, and barricado'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I came through a private vault, which few there know of;
It riſes in a Temple not farre hence,
Cloſe by the Caſtle here.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How—To what end?

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.l: A good one:
To give ye knowledge of my new-borne Miſtris,
And in what doubt Armuſia ſtands,
Thinke any preſent meanes, or hope to ſtop 'em
From their fell ends: the Princes are come in too,
And they are hardn'd alſo.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: The damn'd Prieſt—

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sure he's a cruell man, methinks Religion
Should teach more temperate leſſons.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: He the fire-brand?
He dare to touch at ſuch faire lives as theirs are?
Well Prophet, I ſhall propheſie, I ſhall catch ye,
When all your Prophecies will not redeem yee?
Wilt thou doe one thing bravely?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Any good I am able.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And by thine owne white hand Ile ſweare thou art vertuous,
And a brave wench, durſt thou but guide me preſently
Through the ſame vault thou cam'ſt into the Pallace,
And thoſe I ſhall appoynt, ſuch as I thinke fit.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Yes, I will doe it, and ſuddenly, and truely.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I wou'd faine behold this Prophet.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Now I have yee;
And ſhall bring yee where ye ſhall behold him,
Alone too, and unfurniſh'd of defences:
That ſhall be my care; but you muſt not betray me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Doſt thou think we are ſo baſe? ſuch ſlaves, rogues?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I doe not:
And you ſhall ſee how fairely Ile worke for ye.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I muſt needs ſteale that Prieſt,
Steale him, and hang him.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Do any thing to remove his miſchife, ſtrangle him—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come prethee love.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: You'll offer me no foule play?
The Vault is darke.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: 'Twas well remember'd.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: And ye may —
But I hold ye honeſt.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Honeſt enough, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I am but a poore weak wench; and what with the place,
And your perſwaſions Sir — but I hope you will not;
You know we are often cozn'd.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: If thou doſt feare me,
Why doſt thou put me in minde?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: To let you know ſir,
Though it be in your power, and things fitting to it,
Yet a true gent—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I know what hee'll doe:
Come and remember me, and Ile anſwer thee,
Ile anſwer thee to the full; wee'll call at th'Caſtle,
And then my good guide do thy will; ſha't finde me
A very tractable man.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bak.
sp.l: Let my men guard the gates.

sp.speaker: Syan.
sp.l: And mine the Temple,
For feare the honour of our gods ſhould ſuffer,
And on your lives be watchfull.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And be valiant;
And let's ſee, if theſe Portugalls dare enter;
What their high hearts dare doe: Let's ſee how readily,
The great Ruy Dias will redeem his Countrey-men;
He ſpeaks proud words, and threatens.

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: He is approv'd ſir,
And will put faire for what he promiſes;
I could wiſh friendlier termes,
Yet for our Liberties, and for our gods,
We are bound in our beſt ſervice
Even in the hazard of our lives.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Come up Princes,
And give your counſells, and your helpes, the Fort ſtill
Playes fearfully upon us, beats our buildings,
And turnes our people wild with feares.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Send for the priſoner,
And give us leave to argue. Exit Ba. and Sy. Then,

div.stage: Enter Ruy Dyas, Emanuel, Chriſtoph. Pedro, with Sould.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Come on nobly,
And let the Fort play ſtill, we are
Strong enough to look upon 'em,
And returne at pleaſure; it may
Be on our view they will returne him.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: We will returne 'em ſuch thanks elſe,
Shall make 'im ſcratch where it itches not.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How the people ſtare,
And ſome cry, ſome pray, and ſome curſe heartily:
But it is the King —

div.stage: Enter Syana, Bakam, Quiſara, Armuſia, with Souldiers above.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I cannot blame their wiſedomes,
They are all above, Armuſia chain'd and bound too?
O theſe are thankfull Squiers.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Heare us Ruy Dias,
Be wiſe and heare us, and give ſpeedy anſwer,
Command thy Cannon preſently to ceaſe,
No more to trouble the afflicted People,
Or ſuddenly Armuſias head goes off,
As ſuddenly as ſeeaid.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Stay Sir, be moderate.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Doe nothing that's diſhonourable Ruy Dyas,
Let not the feare of me maſter thy valour;
Purſue 'em ſtill, they are baſe malitious people.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Friend be not deſperate.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I ſcorne your courteſies;
Strike when you dare, a faire arme guide the Gunner,
And may he let flye ſtill with fortune: friend,
Doe me the honour of a ſouldiers funeralls,
The laſt faire Chriſtian right, ſee me ith' ground,
And let the pallace burne firſt, then the Temples,
And on their ſcorn'd gods erect my monument:
Touch not the Princeſſe, as you are a ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Quiſar.
sp.l: Which way you go, ſir,
I muſt follow neceſſary.
One life, and one death.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will you take a truce yet?

div.stage: Enter Pyniero, Soza, and Souldiers with the Governour.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: No, no, goe on:
Look here your god, your Prophet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How came he taken?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I Conjur'd for him King.
I am ſure Curre at an old blinde Prophet.
Ile haunt ye ſuch a falſe knave admirably,
A terrier I; I eartht him, and then ſnapt him;

sp.speaker: Soz.
sp.l: Saving the reverence of your grace, we ſtole him
E'ne out of the next chamber to yee.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Come, come, begin King,
Begin this bloudy matter when you dare;
And yet I ſcorne my ſword ſhould touch the raſcall,
Ile teare him thus before ye. Ha!
What art thou? Pulls his Beard and haire off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How's this!
Art thou a Prophet?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: Come downe Princes.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: VVe are abus'd—
Oh my moſt deare Armuſia—
Off which his chaines. And now my noble ſiſter,
Rejoyce with me, I know yee are pleas'd as I am.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: This is a pretious Prophet. Why Don Governour,
What make you here? how long have you taken orders?

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: VVhy what a wretch
Art thou to work this miſchiefe?
To aſſume this holy ſhape to ruine honour,
Honour and chaſtity?

div.stage: Enter King, and all from above.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I had paid you all,
But fortune plaid the ſlut. Come,
Give me my doome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I cannot ſpeak for wonder.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis I ſir,
And here I ſtay your ſentence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take her friend,
You have halfe perſwaded me to be a Chriſtian,
And with her all the joyes, and all the bleſſings.
VVhy what dreame have we dwelt in?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.l: All peace to yee,
And all the happineſſe of heart dwell with ye,
Children as ſweet and noble as their Parents.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: And Kings at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good Sir forget my raſhneſſe.
And noble Princeſſe, for I was once angrie,
And out of that might utter ſome diſtemper,
Think not 'tis my nature.

sp.speaker: Sya.
sp.l: Your joy is ours ſir,
And nothing we finde in ye, But moſt noble.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To priſon with this dog, there let him houle,
And if he can repent, ſigh out his villanies:
His Iſland we ſhall ſeize into our hands,
His father and himſelfe have both uſurp'd it,
And kept it by oppreſſion; the Towne and Caſtle,
In which I lay my ſelfe moſt miſerable,
Till my moſt honourable friend redeem'd me,
Signeur Pyniero I beſtow on you,
The reſt of next command upon theſe gentlemen,
Upon ye all my love.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: O brave Ruy Dias.
You have ſtarted now beyond me. I muſt thank ye,
And thank ye for my life, my wife and honour.

sp.speaker: Ruy.
sp.l: I am glad I had her for you ſir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Princes,
Come friends and lovers all, come noble gentlemen,
No more guns now, nor hates but joyes and triumphes,
An univerſall gladneſſe flye about us:
And know however ſubtill men dare caſt,
And promiſe wrack, the gods give peace at laſt.
